August 31, 2015. | employees_year = 2014 | volunteers = 230 | volunteers_year = 2014 | tax_id = 53-0219643 | revenue = $2,562,075 | revenue_year = 2015 | expenses = $2,379,375 | expenses_year = 2015 | status = [[501(c)(3)]] [[nonprofit organization]]"[https://apps.irs.gov/app/eos/pub78Search.do?ein1=53-0219643&names=&city=&state=All...&country=US&deductibility=all&dispatchMethod=searchCharities&submitName=Search Federal City Council]". ''Exempt Organizations Select Check''. [[Internal Revenue Service]]. Retrieved March 9, 2017. | website = {{URL|http://www.federalcitycouncil.org}} }} '''Federal City Council''' is a [[501(c)(3)]] [[nonprofit organization]] that promotes economic development in the city of [[Washington, D.C.]], in the United States. Incorporated on September 13, 1954, it is one of the most powerful private groups in the city, and is highly influential in [[United States Congress|Congress]]. It was the primary backer of a wide range of important projects, including the near-complete razing of [[Southwest, Washington, D.C.|Southwest D.C.]] in favor of redevelopment in the 1950s and 1960s, the construction of the [[Washington Metro]] [[Rapid transit|subway]] system, the construction of the [[Washington Convention Center|city's first]] and [[Walter E. Washington Convention Center|second convention centers]], the construction of the [[Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center]], and the construction of the [[Verizon Center]]. It has also been successful in pushing for changes in the [[District of Columbia Public Schools]], reform of the federal role in the District of Columbia's finances, and reform of the District's tax structure. The association, whose members are largely drawn from the business community, prefers to work behind the scenes and avoid media attention. It is highly influential, although assessments of its influence in the past decade have varied. The organization has also created a number of independent nonprofits and subsidiary bodies, which have worked on range of issues, from waterway restoration to crime. ==History== ===Founding and early issues=== The Federal City Council was incorporated on September 13, 1954, "to develop, stimulate and encourage civic leadership in community development in the National Capitol".{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=89}} [[Phil Graham]], co-owner and publisher of ''[[The Washington Post]]'', was the major force in creating the council. Graham was deeply concerned about the decline of the District of Columbia in the post-World War II period and the city's rapid loss of population and business to suburbs in Maryland and Virginia. Graham was also worried that the [[Southwest, Washington, D.C.|Southwest Washington]] urban renewal project, authorized in 1946{{sfn|Subcommittee on Fiscal and Government Affairs|1978|page=112}} and funded in 1949,{{sfn|Gutheim|Lee|2006|page=260}} would be cancelled, ending the city's best chance at turning itself around. In 1952, Graham held a meeting of like-minded top businessmen in the boardroom of Riggs Bank to discuss formation of an organization to counteract these trends. These discussions led to formation of the Federal City Council in 1954. Membership was largely limited to businesspeople, because the group felt that only private sector money and a business-like approach to development and management could improve the District. Among the original members of the group in 1954 were Graham{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=115}} and Francis Addison, Jr., president of Security Bank and former president of the [[Greater Washington Board of Trade|Washington Board of Trade]].{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=151}} [[George A. Garrett]], a former ambassador, was elected the organization's first president on November 16.{{cite news|title=G.A. Garrett Federal City Council Head|work=The Washington Post|date=November 17, 1954|page=A1}} A fundamental concept which the group agreed upon early in its history was to work behind the scenes and only on projects that can shape the city for 20 years or more. The Federal City Council was active in a wide range of issues in the 1950s, including slum clearance,{{cite news|title=Expert Prods District to Rush Slum Clearance|work=The Washington Post|date=February 2, 1955|page=A18|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Allbrook|first=Robert C.|title=Ike Names Garrett to Spur SW Plan|work=The Washington Post|date=March 17, 1955|page=A1}} and is credited with successfully lobbying the Eisenhower administration to expedite the razing of much of Southwest Washington{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=91}}{{cite news|last=Powell|first=Michael|title=Showing Dubious Progress in a Deadly District|work=The Washington Post|date=April 19, 1998|page=A1}}{{Efn|The Federal City Council has also been criticized for pursuing the wholesale demolition of Southwest D.C. As reporter Michael Powell of ''The Washington Post'' put it in 1998: "If there was a distant trigger for the homicides that now beset Washington, many criminologists and activists locate it in this huge dislocation. The destruction of neighborhoods and the grouping of thousands of poor families in isolated public housing at a time of social unrest fed a growing alienation and violence."}} It was also involved in an attempt to locate the headquarters of the [[Central Intelligence Agency]] in the District of Columbia,{{cite news|title=Council Launches a Renewed Effort to Get the CIA to Locate in District|work=The Washington Post|date=December 24, 1955|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Dulles, Planners Agree On CIA Site at Langley|work=The Washington Post|date=March 8, 1956|page=A53}} urban planning,{{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=Civic Group Urges Area Control Body|work=The Washington Post|date=November 20, 1957|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Area Authority of Real Power Also Proposed|work=The Washington Post|date=December 24, 1957|page=B1}} demolition of the temporary [[Main Navy and Munitions Buildings]] on the [[National Mall]],{{cite news|title=Plea Made to Rid D.C. of 'Tempos'|work=The Washington Post|date=May 10, 1958|page=B1}} the site of the proposed [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|D.C. Cultural Center]],{{cite news|title=Culture Site Action Urged Upon House|work=The Washington Post|date=July 30, 1958|page=A11}} and the size of the federal payment made to the city in lieu of [[property taxes]].{{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=Federal City Council Projects Drive to Boost Federal Payment to D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=December 10, 1958|page=A1}} It was particularly active on the [[Theodore Roosevelt Bridge]] issue. It pushed hard for a bridge rather than a tunnel, and, once a bridge had been chosen, for the bridge's location to be about {{convert|800|ft|m}} upstream from the final location.{{cite news|title=Federal Council Enters Bridge-or-Tunnel Debate|work=The Washington Post|date=December 19, 1956|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Civic Group Lauds Bridge Action Move|work=The Washington Post|date=October 1, 1957|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Aid of Federal City Council Sought By Seaton on Relocation of Bridge|work=The Washington Post|date=May 16, 1958|page=D1}} ===1960s: Pushing big economic projects=== [[File:Looking northeast over Southwest Washington DC - July 1939.jpg|thumb|Wholesale demolition of the slums in Southwest D.C. (''depicted'') was a key goal of the Federal City Council.]] Urban planning and the federal contribution to the city's budget continued to occupy some of the Federal City Council's agenda in the early 1960s.{{cite news|last=Allbrook|first=Robert C.|title=Area Citizens Need 'Regional Voice'|work=The Washington Post|date=November 20, 1960|page=E2|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Lindsay|first=John J.|title=NCPC Head Fights Bill to Curb Agency in D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=May 25, 1961|page=D1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Council Asks Congress to Pay Share|work=The Washington Post|date=June 17, 1961|page=D16|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Claiborne|first=William L.|title=Six Years $4 Billion Could Make D.C. Ideal 'Fairgrounds'|work=The Washington Post|date=June 14, 1970|page=C1}} But big economic development projects moved to center stage for the organization. It unsuccessfully pushed for a "Federal City Center" (a vast complex of government office buildings akin to [[Federal Triangle]]) in 1960.{{cite news|last=Landauer|first=Jerry|title=Plan Pushed For Federal City Center|work=The Washington Post|date=July 24, 1960|page=A14}} The organization also pushed hard for construction of the D.C. Cultural Center, even though it lost the battle to erect the auditorium at [[L'Enfant Plaza]].{{cite news|last=Barthelmes|first=Wes|title=SW Auditorium Site Favored|work=The Washington Post|date=November 4, 1956|page=B4|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Landauer|first=Jerry|title=Drive Planned for Convention Hall Here|work=The Washington Post|date=November 27, 1960|page=B1}} It was far more successful in opposing cancellation of the Southwest Washington urban renewal project, which called for razing nearly all buildings in that quadrant of the city and constructing a new urban center. Although the Federal City Council's specific plans were not adopted, it was deeply involved in the planning process and its studies often relied on by Congress.{{cite news|title=Group Raps Bill to Curb D.C. Renewal|work=The Washington Post|date=May 10, 1960|page=B2|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Survey of Urban Renewal Setup Accepted by Federal City Council|work=The Washington Post|date=September 29, 1960|page=A23|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Carberry|first=James R.|title=Bill to Combine RLA, Housing Authority Argued|work=The Washington Post|date=July 21, 1961|page=B7|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Carberry|first=James R.|title=Plan to Merge Renewal Agencies Altered Drastically by House Unit|work=The Washington Post|date=August 3, 1961|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Mintz|first=Morton|title=Future of Renewal Seen Far From Citizen Group's Hopes|work=The Washington Post|date=September 6, 1961|page=B4|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Lindsay|first=John J.|title=Renewal Plans Meet Opposition|work=The Washington Post|date=January 18, 1962|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Committee to Iron Out Legislation on Renewal|work=The Washington Post|date=July 12, 1962|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Clopton|first=Willard|title=2 Agencies Blast Plan to Shift Renewal Setup|work=The Washington Post|date=May 3, 1963|page=A1}} The Federal City Council even raised money to develop its own concepts for redeveloping downtown and Southwest D.C., and lobbied Congress to have its plans adopted. In 1962, it won adoption of its proposal in the House of Representatives. When the bill died in the Senate at the end of the [[87th United States Congress|87th Congress]], it went to the Senate and won passage there in 1963. When the 1963 legislation moved to the House, Representatives [[John Dowdy]] and [[John L. McMillan]] attached a number of [[Rider (legislation)|riders]] to the bill that required [[Procurement|competitive bidding]], forced federal agencies to give displaced businesses priority in receiving federal assistance, required the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) to develop plans for relocating low-income residents, and placed limits on the number of redevelopment projects that could be approved or constructed at any given time. But many liberals in Congress as well as [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development|HUD Secretary]] [[Robert C. Weaver]] opposed these riders.{{sfn|Gillette|2006|page=171}} The riders were enacted into law. Unwilling to see redevelopment of Southwest D.C. collapse, the Federal City Council agreed to sponsor legislation that would authorize the Redevelopment Land Agency (RLA, the federal bureau overseeing the reconstruction of Southwest D.C.) to conduct redevelopment on the same basis as federal agencies in other cities. Although this meant ignoring the Federal City Council's plans for redevelopment, it allowed the RLA to begin acting quickly and decisively on redevelopment projects.{{sfn|Gillette|2006|page=172}} Two of the major projects the Federal City Council pushed for in the 1960s were [[Inner Loop (Washington, D.C.)|Inner Loop]] highway system and its associated [[Three Sisters Bridge (District of Columbia)|Three Sisters Bridge]], and the [[Washington Metro]] subway system. The Inner Loop was strongly opposed by local citizens, who felt it was unnecessary, destroyed many neighborhoods, and despoiled the environment. However, Representative [[William Huston Natcher|William Natcher]], chairman of the Subcommittee on Appropriations for the District of Columbia of the [[United States House Committee on Appropriations|House Committee on Appropriations]], was not only a strong advocate of bridge and highway construction but also convinced that construction of the Inner Loop was essential to the growth of the District of Columbia. The Federal City Council, too, advocated the Inner Loop as a response to the flight of retail and light industry for the suburbs (a trend which began in the 1950s). The organization believed that quick and easy automobile access to the city (with lots of inexpensive parking) would draw shoppers and retailers back. A large subway system was equally important, as the Federal City Council concluded that surface transit alone could not meet the needs of the rapidly growing D.C. metropolitan area. The organization pushed hard for construction of Metro even though Representative Natcher threatened to cancel the subway project if the Inner Loop was not constructed.{{cite news|title=Action Called Major Step for Both Projects|work=The Washington Post|date=April 7, 1961|page=D1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Clopton|first=Willard|title=Put Downtown Subway First, Council Urges|work=Washington Post|date=May 5, 1963|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Both Transit, Roads Backed By Council|work=Washington Post|date=June 22, 1963|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=Width and Design of Freeway Draw Criticism at D.C. Hearing|work=Washington Post|date=September 4, 1963|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Business Units Fear Second Freeway War|work=Washington Post|date=June 2, 1964|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Schuette|first=Paul A.|title=Rapid Transit Rail Urged by Policy Group|work=Washington Post|date=October 1, 1964|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Federal Council Asks Road Delay|work=Washington Post|date=January 18, 1965|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Resumption of Freeway Plan Urged|work=Washington Post|date=April 25, 1966|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=NCPC Board Seeks Delay In Freeways|work=Washington Post|date=April 26, 1966|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=New Freeway Plan Provides Housing Sites|work=Washington Post|date=April 29, 1966|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=Agreement Reached on Highways|work=Washington Post|date=May 26, 1966|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Carper|first=Elsie|title=Senate Subcommittee Joins In Praise of Channel Bridge|work=Washington Post|date=August 24, 1966|page=C9|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Levey|first1=Bob|last2=Levey|first2=Jane Freundel|title=End of the Roads|work=The Washington Post|date=November 26, 2000|page=WMAG10}} The organization also wished to ensure that wealthier suburbanites would be able to reach the downtown D.C. shopping district, in the hopes this would reverse or at least stop the flight of retail out of the city.{{cite news|title=L'Enfant's legacy: A worthy capital?|work=The Economist|date=April 16, 1988|page=64}} As part of its Inner Loop push, the Federal City Council asked the City Commission to "[[Nationalization|nationalize]]" all parking the city. This was a major step, for it meant government ownership of all [[parking lot]]s, [[Multi-storey car park|parking garages]], and [[valet parking]] lots in the city. The Washington Parking Association, a trade association of parking lot owners, strongly opposed the move. Although the City Commission was willing to pass nationalization legislation, there was extensive opposition in Congress (which had the power to overturn any city law), and the measure died.{{cite news|last=Downie|first=Leonard, Jr.|title=Federal City Unit Charges Distortion By Private Group on Parking Here|work=The Washington Post|date=July 12, 1965|page=B3|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Morgan|first=Dan|title=Approval Postponed On Public Parking Bill|work=The Washington Post|date=December 23, 1965|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Board of Trade Shifts, Supports Parking Bill|work=The Washington Post|date=January 11, 1966|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Morgan|first=Dan|title=City's Disappearing Parking Lots Key Issue in Legislative Hassle|work=The Washington Post|date=March 25, 1966|page=A1}} Other, smaller projects with the Federal City Council worked on during the 1960s included another attempt to get rid of the "tempos" on the National Mall,{{cite news|title=Task Force to Rid City of Tempos|work=The Washington Post|date=December 22, 1963|page=A10}} construction of a "national aquarium" in [[East Potomac Park]],{{cite news|last=White|first=Jean|title=Aquarium Goes to Potomac Park, With Span Planned to Maine Ave|work=The Washington Post|date=June 16, 1964|page=B1}} and a major boost in police to create a "war on crime".{{cite news|title=D.C. Crime War Backed By Federal City Council|work=The Washington Post|date=March 3, 1967|page=A19}} The agenda of the Federal City Council could also work against democracy in the District of Columbia. During the 1960s, there was an increasingly strong push for [[District of Columbia home rule]]. Because it supported the vested interests of the status quo, the Federal City Council strongly opposed home rule. It opposed initiatives supported by home rule activists, and often proposed and pushed for the adoption of plans that home rule advocates opposed. In order to win support for its proposals, the Federal City Council raised money to re-elect members of the powerful [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform|House Committee on the District of Columbia]]—most of whom also opposed home rule, as it significantly reduced their power in Congress.{{sfn|Fauntroy|2003|page=47}} ===1970s: Focus on economic development=== [[File:DCConventionCenter.jpg|thumb|The Federal City Council successfully pushed for construction of D.C.'s first convention center.]] Although portions of the Inner Loop were constructed, the majority of highways that comprised the system (including the elements most destructive of neighborhoods and the environment) were cancelled by federal court decisions and by changes in national transportation policy during the late 1960s and the early 1970s.{{sfn|Gutheim|Lee|2006|page=297}} The [[Three Sisters Bridge]] project was killed in the House of Representatives in early December 1971.{{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=House Releases District Subway Funds|work=The Washington Post|date=December 3, 1971|page=A1}} With the Inner Loop dead, the Federal City Council continued to push for city-owned parking and for full funding of the Metro system.{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=Eugene L.|title=Council to Step Into Parking Jam|work=The Washington Post.'' April 5, 1970|page=D1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Feaver|first=Douglas B.|title=Full System For Metro Is Backed|work=The Washington Post|date=December 21, 1977|page=B1}} With federal funds for massive infrastructure development dwindling fast in the early 1970s, the Federal City Council turned its focus to smaller projects that would spur economic development. One of its key issues was the construction of a [[Washington Convention Center|Dwight D. Eisenhower Convention Center]] to make the city attractive to large trade association conventions. The push for a convention center began in 1973. Although there was extensive opposition in Congress at first, the Federal City Council lobbied hard for federal approval. This was finally given in 1978.{{cite news|last=Scharfenberg|first=Kirk.|title=Center's Planning Financed|work=The Washington Post|date=April 5, 1973|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Barker|first1=Karlyn|last2=Hamilton|first2=Martha M.|title=Project Held Boon for Old Downtown Landowners|work=The Washington Post|date=July 3, 1978|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Baker|first=Donald P.|title=Civic Center In D.C. Wins Hill Backing|work=The Washington Post|date=November 3, 1978|page=A1}} The Washington Convention Center finally opened in December 1982.{{cite news|last=Pianin|first=Eric|title=Gala Debut Is Set For Long-Awaited Convention Center|work=The Washington Post|date=December 10, 1982|page=B1}} The Federal City Council also backed a "D.C. Building Corporation" to assist developers in obtaining financing for major projects,{{cite news|last=Lippman|first=Thomas W.|title=Fauntroy Backs D.C. Building Corporation|work=The Washington Post|date=June 23, 1974|page=B4|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Jones|first=William H.|title=City Economic Health Bleak, Tucker Says|work=The Washington Post|date=October 28, 1975|page=B5|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Jones|first=William H.|title=Government, Business Grapple With D.C. Economic Problems|work=The Washington Post|date=June 5, 1977|page=A53}} and pushed the city to create an economic development strategic plan.{{cite news|last=Jones|first=William H.|title=Development Plan Sought By the Mayor|work=The Washington Post|date=June 28, 1979|page=C1}} As part of its economic redevelopment initiative, the Federal City Council also sought to repeal [[Rent control in the United States|rent control]] laws in the District of Columbia. Rent control, the organization argued, discouraged new housing from being built in the city and retarded the city's economic growth. The city's rent control law, enacted in 1975, was seen as vulnerable by the Federal City Council in 1975 and 1976, as few residents had seen its benefits and did not yet support it.{{cite news|last=Dewar|first=Helen|title=Rent Control Seen Curbing Unsubsidized City Housing|work=The Washington Post|date=September 30, 1975|page=C2|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Whitaker|first=Joseph D.|title=New Housing Called Prime Need in D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=September 30, 1975|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Rent Control Seen Bar to D.C. Units|work=The Washington Post|date=April 3, 1976|page=D28}} Its repeal attempt was unsuccessful, however. The Federal City Council also began unsuccessfully pushing in the late 1970s for a regional economic planning board similar to the urban planning body it had pressed for in the 1950s.{{cite news|last=Baker|first=Donald P.|title=Proposed Planning Panel Attacked on Hill|work=The Washington Post|date=February 24, 1978|page=C2|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Jones|first=William H.|title=Regional Approach For D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=May 31, 1978|page=E1}} ===1980s: The trade center, crime, and schools=== In the 1980s, the Federal City Council backed two plans—one to reduce flights at [[Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport|Washington National Airport]] and another to redevelop [[Buzzard Point]]—at the opening and close of the decade.{{cite news|last=Feaver|first=Douglas B.|title=Plan to Cut National Flights Is Backed|work=The Washington Post|date=July 11, 1980|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Hilzenrath|first=David S.|title=Official, Developers Share a Vision for Buzzard Point|work=The Washington Post|date=August 20, 1988|page=E1}} Neither plan was implemented. It also released a study in 1980 criticizing the District government for allowing significant deterioration in the city's {{convert|1300|mi|km}} of water pipes. (The city took no action until a series of major pipeline breaks led to emergency action in 1993.){{cite news|last=Spayd|first=Liz|title=D.C. Was Alerted More Than 10 Years Ago About Aging Water Pipes|work=The Washington Post|date=December 28, 1993|page=A1}} [[File:Ronald Reagan Bld.jpg|thumb|The Federal City Council initiated the effort to build the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center, which completed the Federal Triangle complex.]] The concept for a massive "trade center", which would become an international headquarters for corporations and trade associations, was a more successful project. In June 1983, the Federal City Council proposed that a huge $300 million structure be built on unused land adjacent to [[Maine Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|Maine Avenue SW]]. Despite local citizen opposition, the organization convinced [[Mayor of the District of Columbia|D.C. Mayor]] [[Marion Barry]] to begin pushing the plan through the [[Council of the District of Columbia|D.C. City Council]] and Congress. Opposition from executive branch agencies, however, derailed the plan, and by 1986 the Federal City Council was looking for an alternative site for the building. In late 1986, the association began pushing for construction of the trade center on a parking lot in [[Federal Triangle]], an area originally intended for a major government office building in the 1930s but never built due to the financial distress caused by the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]]. This site won near-universal approval, and in 1987 Congress authorized construction of the [[Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center]].{{cite news|last=Struck|first=Myron|title='Trade Center' Planned for D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=June 11, 1983|page=F1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=World Class on the Waterfront|work=The Washington Post|date=June 16, 1983|page=A28|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Teeley|first=Sandra Evans|title=Objections to SW Trade Center Prompt City Review of Plans for Waterfront|work=The Washington Post|date=July 5, 1983|page=B5|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Slacum|first=Marcia A.|title=Mayor Seeks Council's Backing for Cultural and Trade Center|work=The Washington Post|date=January 13, 1984|page=B8|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Harris|first=Lyle V.|title=SW Plan's Future Uncertain|work=The Washington Post|date=July 25, 1984|page=DC1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Mintz|first=John|title=New Sites Eyed In District for Trade Center|work=The Washington Post|date=May 23, 1986|page=C8|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Havemann|first=Judith|title=Trade Center Draws Support|work=The Washington Post|date=October 30, 1986|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Havemann|first=Judith|title=Completion of Federal Triangle Voted|work=The Washington Post|date=August 8, 1987|page=A1}} Donald A. Brown, who chaired the Federal City Council's International Center Task Force, was one of five people nominated to the U.S. International Cultural and Trade Center Commission, which served as a board of supervisors overseeing the construction of the building.{{cite news|title=5 Named to Panel On Cultural Center|work=The Washington Post|date=April 7, 1988|page=J5}} Terence Golden, who was director of the federal government's [[General Services Administration]] (GSA) and who helped shepherd the legislation authorizing the building through Congress, later was elected chairman of the board of directors of the Federal City Council.{{cite news|last=Shin|first=Annys|title=Think Mogully, Act Locally|work=Washington City Paper|date=February 14, 2003|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/articles/25599/think-mogully-act-locally}} Originally intended to cost $363 million, the $818 million Ronald Reagan Building opened on May 5, 1998, after years of funding and construction delays.{{cite news|last1=Montgomery|first1=David|last2=Wheeler|first2=Linda|title=A Soaring Reagan Tribute|work=The Washington Post|date=May 6, 1998|page=A1}} The construction of the Washington Metro and development of the federal government became major issues for the Federal City Council in the mid-1980s. The group received approximately $250,000 in August 1985 to study the transit needs of the area through the year 2000, the first time a group independent of Metro was authorized by the federal government to conduct such a study.{{cite news|last=Bruske|first=Ed|title=DOT Awards Metro System Study|work=The Washington Post|date=August 17, 1985|page=B4}} The organization's study, released in March 1986, said Metro faced a financial crisis by 2000 caused by significant cuts in federal funds as well as rapidly growing capital improvement needs (such as replacing subway cars and worn equipment and track).{{cite news|last=Lynton|first=Stephen J.|title=Rapidly Rising Costs Forecast for Subway Equipment Upkeep|work=The Washington Post|date=March 12, 1986|page=C1}} In December 1986, the Federal City Council issued a report that recommended that the federal government undertake a 10-year plan to construct new federal office buildings rather than lease space for federal agencies.{{cite news|last=Havemann|first=Judith|title=U.S. Urged to Rent Less Private Office Space|work=The Washington Post|date=December 2, 1986|page=C1}} The proposal seemed to die, but in 1990 the GSA incorporated its key recommendations into a new office space consolidation policy. GSA even proposed building a new [[United States Department of Transportation]] headquarters using [[air rights]] above the railroad tracks north of [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]]. The financing model for the structure had "the fingerprints of the Federal City Council all over it."{{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title=Dusting Off the Federal City Council's Approaches to Office Space|work=The Washington Post|date=January 18, 1990|page=C3}}{{Efn|The project never went forward. Instead, in 2002, the D.C.-based real estate development firm [[Akridge]] partnered with New York City-based investment fund Leucadia National Corporation (now known as [[Jefferies Group|Jeffries]]) to build Burnham Place—a $1.5 billion [[Mixed-use development|mixed-use]] development that will build a new passenger terminal and retail, residential, and office buildings over the tracks (while adding a large parking garage beneath the tracks).{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=Eugene L.|title=Union Station in Washington Has a Grand Development Plan|work=The New York Times|date=April 14, 2015|accessdate=November 28, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/15/realestate/commercial/union-station-in-washington-has-a-grand-development-plan.html}}}} The Federal City Council actively pushed for redevelopment of the northwest bank of the [[Anacostia River]] as a means of creating room for more federally owned office buildings as well as redeveloping the District of Columbia. The [[General Services Administration]] initially tried to lure the [[Securities and Exchange Commission]] to [[Buzzard Point]] by offering to construct it a new office building there in 1978, but this effort failed. By 1988, however, the Federal City Council was part heavily involved with the city government, the federal government, and private landowners to plan a redevelopment of the warehouse area into apartment and office buildings, parks, and retail space.{{cite news|last=Hilzenrath|first=David S.|title=Officials, Developers Share a Vision for Buzzard Point|work=The Washington Post|date=August 20, 1988|page=E1}}{{Efn|Nothing came of these plans. Instead, in 2012, the District of Columbia announced a plan to replace and slightly realign the [[Frederick Douglass Memorial Bridge]]. This plan included creation of a massive, oval [[Roundabout|traffic circle]] with a large field (to be used for public gatherings, and suitable for several new memorials) at the north end of the bridge, reconnecting it with Potomac Avenue SW.{{cite news|last=Halsey|first=Ashley III|title=Decaying D.C. Bridge Reflects State of Thousands of Such Structures Nationwide|work=The Washington Post|date=December 31, 2012|accessdate=January 27, 2013|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/2012/12/30/22fc8f18-454c-11e2-9648-a2c323a991d6_story.html|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Rebuilding Bridges in the District|work=The Washington Post|date=December 31, 2012|accessdate=January 27, 2013|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/rebuilding-bridges-in-the-district/2012/12/31/052b1dec-537a-11e2-8b9e-dd8773594efc_graphic.html}} The government of the District of Columbia budgeted $512.7 million over six years, beginning in fiscal 2016, to begin building the bridge.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/breaking_ground/2015/04/new-building-new-debt-and-crazy-housing-prices-a.html|last=Neibauer|first=Michael|title=New building, new debt and crazy housing prices: A dive into D.C.'s 2016 budget proposal|work=Washington Business Journal|date=April 7, 2015|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} In July 2013, the city and the [[D.C. United]] professional [[Association football|soccer]] club signed an agreement to build a new soccer stadium on Buzzard Point. The city agreed to acquire some land at the site, and lease the land to the club for a minimal rent. The club agreed to build the stadium.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/mayor-gray-dc-united-reach-tentative-deal-on-soccer-stadium-for-buzzard-point/2013/07/24/b3c6594e-f315-11e2-ae43-b31dc363c3bf_story.html|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=Mayor Gray, D.C. United reach tentative deal on soccer stadium for Buzzard Point|work=The Washington Post|date=July 24, 2013|accessdate=April 13, 2015}} Demolition and site preparation began in August 2016.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/soccer-insider/wp/2016/04/25/d-c-united-stadium-plans-taking-shape-at-buzzard-point/|last=Goff|first=Steven|title=D.C. United stadium plans taking shape at Buzzard Point|work=Washington Post|date=April 25, 2016|accessdate=August 26, 2016}}}} In the late 1980s, the Federal City Council turned its attention to crime rather than development. By this time, Washington, D.C., was suffering from an epidemic of [[crack cocaine]] use. The drug made an appearance in the United States in 1981, and by the end of 1986 was deeply entrenched in the District of Columbia.{{sfn|Haley|2009|page=27}} The following year, one study estimated that there were 24,000 drug dealers in the city (38.6 per 1,000 residents), with at least 14,000 of them dealing on a regular basis (at least one day per week).{{sfn|Lusane|Desmond|1991|page=173}} By one estimate, cocaine and crack cocaine use doubled in the city between 1986 and 1987.{{sfn|Lusane|Desmond|1991|page=170}} A private study estimated that one in six African American men in the city were arrested for selling illegal drugs before the age of 21, and by 1990 a shocking one in four African American men in the city had sold drugs before the age of 30.{{sfn|Lusane|Desmond|1991|page=170}} By 1990, the District of Columbia had the nation's highest rate of drug addiction (32.9 per 1,000 residents).{{sfn|Lusane|Desmond|1991|page=170}} The crack cocaine epidemic drove the city's murder rate in 1988 to 372,{{sfn|Leon|2010|page=79}} and 80 percent of the city's murders were drug-related.{{sfn|Walsh|Ellis|2007|page=269}} With drug-related crime outstripping by far economic development as the city's largest problem, in 1986 the Federal City Council joined with the Community Foundation, the [[Greater Washington Board of Trade]], and the Greater Washington Research Center to form the Washington Fund for the Prevention of Substance Abuse.{{cite news|last=Duke|first=Lynne|title=Suburban Drug Use Here Worst in U.S.|work=The Washington Post|date=February 26, 1988|page=A1}} By October 1988, the Federal City Council also sponsored the creation of the Corporation Against Drug Abuse (CADA), an employer-funded entity to encourage the adoption of stricter drug testing and drug abuse policies in the workplace and to work against drug abuse generally in the community.{{cite news|last=Duke|first=Lynne|title=A Corporate Attack on Drugs|work=The Washington Post|date=October 25, 1988|page=A1}} As part of its interest in social programs, the Federal City Council also turned its attention for the first time to the [[District of Columbia Public Schools]] (DCPS). DCPS Superintendent Andrew E. Jenkins awarded the organization a $500,000 grant to assemble a team of 51 community leaders and review DCPS curricula, budget, extra-curricular programs, and educational goals and priorities. The grant was one of the largest ever made by the school system. The report, due in June 1989, was expected to guide the DCPS system through the 1990s.{{cite news|last=Sanchez|first=Rene|title=Group of 'Doers' to Scrutinize How Well D.C. Schools Educate|work=The Washington Post|date=November 29, 1988|page=B5}} To build support for implementing the report's findings, the council created the D.C. Committee on Public Education (a group of parents and business, religious, and civic leaders), in 1988.{{cite news|last=Horwitz|first=Sari|title=D.C.'s School Chief Wins Panel's Praise|work=The Washington Post|date=June 24, 1993|page=D3}} When released on June 20, 1989, the report recommended spending $355 million over the next five years to extend the school day by five hours (to a 7 A.M. to 6 P.M. schedule); extend the school year by 40 days; construct new schools; repair existing schools; and add stronger math and science programs and multicultural education to the curriculum. To pay for the plan, the Federal City Council's team suggested cutting administrative costs by $8.5 million, eliminating 400 central staff positions, closing some schools, and selling some school property.{{cite news|last=Johnson|first=Julie|title=Far-Reaching Changes Urged in Capital's Schools|work=The New York Times|date=June 21, 1989|accessdate=November 21, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/06/21/us/education-far-reaching-changes-urged-in-capital-s-schools.html}} The Committee on Public Education remained active for many years, issuing reports critical of the public school system.{{cite news|last=Horwitz|first=Sari|title=D.C. Schools Declining, Report Says|work=The Washington Post|date=January 18, 1995|page=D5}} In 1989, the Federal City Council issued a report castigating the government of the District of Columbia for allowing the city's roads to deteriorate. The report noted that the city spent just $5 million a year on road repair, which it used almost exclusively for temporary patches rather than permanent repair, upgrades, and maintenance. The report identified a $1.6 billion backlog in street maintenance projects.{{cite news|last1=French|first1=Mary Ann|last2=Fehr|first2=Stephen C.|title=D.C. Gets $19 Million For Roads|work=The Washington Post|date=December 7, 1990|page=B1}} The backlogs led the city to separate its road maintenance, repair, and construction functions from the [[District of Columbia Department of Public Works]], creating a new [[District Department of Transportation]] in 2002.{{cite report|last=Goldstein|first=Mark L.|title=District of Columbia's Department of Transportation's Reorganization and Use of Federal-Aid Funding. GAO-04-644R|location=Washington, D.C.|publisher=United States General Accounting Office|date=May 14, 2004|accessdate=November 28, 2016|page=1|url=http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d04644r.pdf}} ===1990s: The new convention center and new sports arena=== [[File:Verizon Center wide.jpg|thumb|The Verizon Center (formerly the MCI Center) was built after the Federal City Council completed negotiations with sports team owner Abe Pollin.]] [[File:Washington, D.C. Convention Center.JPG|thumb|The new Walter E. Washington Convention Center was pushed by the Federal City Council as a replacement for the city's first convention center.]] The Federal City Council helped win financing for a new Washington Convention Center. The existing convention center opened on December 10, 1982. But just eight years later, the facility's small size and a nationwide boom in the construction of large convention centers had caused the {{convert|285000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} facility to see a dramatic drop in business.{{cite news|last=Hedgpeth|first=Dana|title=Convention Group's Chief Quits|work=The Washington Post|date=March 24, 2000|page=E1}} The Federal City Council pushed hard for the construction of a new, much larger convention center, and helped the city fashion ways to finance it. When the project encountered resistance from the business community and Congress, the Federal City Council mobilized its membership to come out publicly in support of the arena. In May 1990, the city unveiled plans for a new $685 million, {{convert|2300000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} convention center{{cite news|last=Melton|first=R.H.|title=Convention Center Plans Unveiled|work=The Washington Post|date=May 30, 1990|page=D1}} backed by the Federal City Council and the Board of Trade.{{cite news|last=Spayd|first=Liz|title=D.C. Coalition Endorses New Convention Center|work=The Washington Post|date=August 14, 1993|page=C1}} Ground was broken for the new [[Walter E. Washington Convention Center]] on October 2, 1998.{{cite news|last=Evans|first=Judith|title=High Hopes Surround Convention Center|work=The Washington Post|date=October 2, 1998|page=F1}} Another project which the Federal City Council supported was construction of the MCI Center (now the [[Verizon Center]]) in [[Chinatown (Washington, D.C.)|Chinatown]]. Along with the Greater Washington Board of Trade and other private groups, the Federal City Council—not public officials, fans, or sports interests—pushed for a new arena downtown.{{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=Group Planning Downtown D.C. Arena to Attract Bullets, Capitals|work=The Washington Post|date=February 10, 1994|page=B1}} [[Abe Pollin]] was the owner of the [[Washington Capitals]] and [[Washington Wizards|Washington Bullets]], professional hockey and basketball teams (respectively) which played at the [[Capital Centre]] in [[Landover, Maryland]]. But the Capital Centre was a small, aging facility, and there seemed an opportunity to bring the teams back into the District of Columbia. The effort began in the summer of 1993, when Federal City Council president [[Ann Dore McLaughlin]] had a casual conversation with [[Gordon Gund]], owner of the [[Cleveland Cavaliers]] professional basketball team, and learned of the "Cleveland model" for a public-private partnership to build a basketball arena in downtown [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. McLaughlin later shared this information with then-D.C. Mayor [[Sharon Pratt Kelly]], who was enthusiastic but emphasized that the private sector must take the lead on the effort. McLaughlin began having talks with Pollin's friends and associates, and members of Pollin's staff. In early November, the Board of Trade sought and won a meeting with Pollin.{{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=D.C. Jumped at Chance to Grab Pro Teams|work=The Washington Post|date=June 12, 1994|page=B1}} Pollin said he had received several offers to sell both teams, and was likely to do so unless a first-class sports arena could be built. On December 16, the Federal City Council hosted a meeting with the Board of Trade, Chamber of Commerce, and city officials to decide to take action. The Federal City Council, Board of Trade, and [[D.C. Chamber of Commerce]] agreed at the meeting to jointly conduct a study of the arena issue. The study identified several challenges, but also discovered that many sports teams were moving back into downtown areas from suburban sites.{{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title=Hoops and Hockey? The Real Game Is Over Where Pollin's Teams Play|work=The Washington Post|date=February 17, 1994|page=B13}} The study also identified several potential sites for the new arena. The city dropped out of the project so as not to appear to be raiding another jurisdiction's sports teams. The Greater Washington Board of Trade initially led talks with Pollin, which began in mid-January, until Maryland officials pointed out that—as a representative of businesses in Maryland and Virginia, not just D.C.—the group had a conflict of interest.{{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title=Backdoor Politics Make for Ugly Sport In Discussing a New D.C. Arena|work=The Washington Post|date=June 13, 1994|page=E3}} Wanting to bring the sports teams back to the city, the Federal City Council took over the talks and successfully convinced Pollin to move his teams.{{cite news|last1=Heath|first1=Thomas|last2=Henderson|first2=Nell|title=City Arena Considered|work=The Washington Post|date=April 16, 1994|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Sell|first=Dave|title=Pollin: Plan 'Interesting'|work=The Washington Post|date=April 23, 1994|page=D1|postscript=none}}{{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=D.C. May Have Deal for Downtown Sports Arena|work=The Washington Post|date=June 7, 1994|page=D1}} The Federal City Council hired several nationally known sports arena and financial consultants to conduct research into the financial feasibility of the proposed arena. These consultants also participated in talks with Pollin. The Federal City Council also successfully pressed the city to provide financing for the project and to help clear away permitting and construction hurdles.{{cite news|last=Leonhardt|first=David|title=Arena Bid Challenges Way D.C. Does Business|work=The Washington Post|date=August 28, 1994|page=B1}}{{cite news|last1=Heath|first1=Thomas|last2=Asher|first2=Mark|title=Md. Running Fast Break on D.C. Arena|work=The Washington Post|date=June 8, 1994|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Heath|first1=Thomas|last2=Asher|first2=Mark|title=D.C. Gets 30-Day Shot at Completing Arena Deal|work=The Washington Post|date=June 21, 1994|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=Regional Game Plan Heavy On Construction|work=The Washington Post|date=December 1, 1996|page=A1}} Construction on the MCI Center began in 1994 and ended in 1995. The Federal City Council was less successful in keeping the [[Washington Redskins]] professional [[American football|football]] team in town. In 1991 and 1992, team owner [[Jack Kent Cooke]] wanted a new stadium, but the cash-strapped city wanted to renovate [[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium]]. When talks between the city and Cooke broke down, Federal City Council officials tried to restart them. Cooke cancelled the talks, and then announced he was building [[FedExField|a new stadium]] in [[Landover, Maryland]].{{cite news|last=Barker|first=Karlyn|title=D.C. Negotiators Feeling Burned by Cooke's Deal|work=The Washington Post|date=July 12, 1992|page=B1}} The Federal City Council and its Committee on Public Education remained active on education issues in the 1990s. The council promoted privatization of the city's public schools in early 1994,{{cite news|last=Horwitz|first=Sari|title=School Privatization Shelved|work=The Washington Post|date=March 4, 1994|page=A1}} and the committee issued a major report in January 1995 strongly criticizing the performance of the District of Columbia Public Schools. Although there were some improvements, the school system had declined in quality in the past six years, the report said. In June 1995, the Federal City Council endorsed private management of low-performing schools.{{cite news|last=Horwitz|first=Sari|title=Private Management of Schools Revisited|work=The Washington Post|date=June 9, 1995|page=D3}} The Federal City Council also opposed casino gambling in the District,{{cite news|last1=Spayd|first1=Liz|last2=Woodlee|first2=Yolanda|title=Trade Board Rejects D.C. Casino Plan|work=The Washington Post|date=September 25, 1993|page=A1}} and paid for a study of the District's finances which was highly critical of the city's excessive spending and lack of revenue.{{cite news|last1=Henderson|first1=Nell|last2=Melton|first2=R.H.|title=D.C. Deficit Could Hit $40 Million|work=The Washington Post|date=September 27, 1994|page=A1}} It supported a 1995 plan by Mayor [[Marion Barry]] to spend $2 billion improving [[New York Avenue (Washington, D.C.)|New York Avenue NE]],{{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=N.Y. Avenue's Future Faces a Rough Road|work=The Washington Post|date=July 31, 1995|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=New Look Avenue: D.C. Panel's $2 Billion Plan for New York|work=The Washington Post|date=September 16, 1996|page=B1}} efforts to build a local cultural center,{{cite news|last=Trescott|first=Jacqueline|title=D.C. Development Spurs Arts Supporters|work=The Washington Post|date=May 6, 1998|page=D2}} downtown revitalization,{{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title=A 'Living Downtown' Needs Places in Which to Live|work=The Washington Post|date=June 29, 1998|page=F4}} an effort to give the District a [[Non-voting members of the United States House of Representatives|delegate]] in the [[United States Senate]],{{cite news|title=The GOP's Hidden Agenda on D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=August 24, 2003|page=B8}} and a National Museum of American Music (to be part of the [[Smithsonian Institution]]).{{cite news|title=Museum Plan Springs From Sinatra Wish|work=Chicago Tribune|date=July 9, 1998|page=2|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Vise|first=David A.|title=Larger Surplus Projected For D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=July 22, 1998|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Fehr|first1=Stephen C.|last2=Hsu|first2=Spencer S.|title=Land, Music Museum Slated for Funds|work=The Washington Post|date=February 8, 2000|page=A15|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=D.C. Site Pushed for Music Museum|work=The Washington Post|date=July 26, 2000|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Big Land, Big Plans|work=The Washington Post|date=July 31, 2000|page=A9}}{{Efn|The idea for a music museum emerged out of a Federal City Council subcommittee called the Downtown Interactive Task Force, created in the early 1990s. Led by are real estate executive Herbert S. Miller, the task force was charged with coming up with ideas for ways to revitalize downtown D.C. The music museum was never built after Senator [[Kay Bailey Hutchison]] opposed the plan in October 2000.{{cite news|title=Metro In Brief|work=The Washington Post|date=October 16, 2000|page=B3}} The Federal City Council revived the plan in the fall of 2003,{{cite news|last=Trescott|first=Jacqueline|title=Music Museum Backers Tune Up For Campaign|work=The Washington Post|date=September 16, 2003|page=C1}} but the idea gained little traction after the city decided not to support the project with donated land in 2004.{{cite news|last1=Irwin|first1=Neil|last2=Hedgpeth|first2=Dana|title=Library Wins in Current Site Plan|work=The Washington Post|date=July 16, 2004|page=E1}} The council signed a lease in 2008 to house the museum at the [[Carnegie Library of Washington D.C.]]—a site it had rejected in 2004—but backed out of the lease. This led to a lawsuit by the library's owner, the [[Historical Society of Washington, D.C.]]{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Nikita|title=Funds to Historical Society in Question|work=The Washington Post|date=October 29, 2010|page=B1}}}} In the late 1990s, the Federal City Council adopted its first strategic plan. ===2000s: Moving away from economic development=== [[File:Michelle Rhee.jpg|thumb|The Federal City Council actively promoted the mayoral takeover of D.C.'s public schools, which led to the hiring of new schools Chancellor Michelle Rhee.]] Under the leadership of chairman Terence Golden in the late 1990s and early 2000s, the Federal City Council began changing its focus away from big-budget infrastructure projects and toward more "community living" initiatives such as the creation of affordable housing, improved public schools, anti-drug and anti-crime initiatives, and support programs for at-risk youth.{{cite news|last=Bisnow|first=Mark|title=The Back Page|work=Washington Business Journal|date=March 28, 2005|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2005/03/28/editorial3.html}} The organization spent two years trying to convince the federal government to reopen [[Pennsylvania Avenue|Pennsylvania Avenue NW]] in front of the [[White House]] (to no avail){{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=Opening 'America's Main Street'|work=The Washington Post|date=August 25, 2000|page=B1}}{{cite news|last=Forgey|first=Benjamin|title=A Chance to Restore a Symbol Of an Open Society|work=The Washington Post|date=September 30, 2000|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Fehr|first=Stephen C.|title=Avenue Plan a Culmination of Frustration|work=The Washington Post|date=October 1, 2000|page=C1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=Architects Offer Plan To Reopen Pa. Avenue|work=The Washington Post|date=February 10, 2001|page=B5|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=Pennsylvania Avenue Opening Gets New Push|work=The Washington Post|date=March 22, 2001|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=Commission to Urge Keeping Avenue Closed|work=The Washington Post|date=November 1, 2001|page=B7}} pushed a [[United States Constitution|Constitutional amendment]] to give the District a seat in the House,{{cite news|last=Sheridan|first=Mary Beth|title=D.C. Vote Advocates Jack Up Pressure|work=The Washington Post|date=June 27, 2007|page=B1}} and supported a legal brief in ''[[District of Columbia v. Heller]]'', 554 U.S. 570 (2008), supporting the city's strict gun control law.{{cite news|title=Let the District Have Its Gun Law|work=The Washington Post|date=January 20, 2008|page=B8}} It did, however, support one major construction project, the new [[Nationals Park]] (a baseball stadium for the city's new [[Major League Baseball]] franchise, the [[Washington Nationals]]).{{cite news|last1=Nakamura|first1=David|last2=Montgomery|first2=Lori|title=Commission to Urge Keeping Avenue Closed|work=The Washington Post|date=November 9, 2004|page=A1}} Education reform continued to draw the organization's attention as well. The Federal City Council funded a study of the school system's administration, staff training, and curriculum by [[McKinsey & Company]] in 2001. The study led the D.C. Public Schools to adopt a five-year plan, titled "Business Plan for Strategic Reform", for making system wide improvements.{{cite news|last=Blum|first=Justin|title=District Readies Schools Shake-Up|work=The Washington Post|date=July 29, 2001|page=C1}} Two years later, the organization partnered with the [[Jim Kimsey|Kimsey Foundation]] and the Morino Institute to fund on-the-job training for 40 school principals over five years.{{cite news|last=Moreno|first=Sylvia|title=D.C. Schools Tapped For Principal Training|work=The Washington Post|date=February 3, 2003|page=B4}} In 2004, the Federal City Council led an effort to raise private money to help improve the salary of the Superintendent of the District of Columbia Public Schools. The move came as the city struggled to find a replacement for [[Paul L. Vance]], who resigned in November 2003.{{cite news|last1=Montgomery|first1=Lori|last2=Blum|first2=Justin|title=Next Head Of Schools May Get $600,000|work=The Washington Post|date=May 13, 2004|page=B1}} In 2006, the organization quietly told city officials that it was deeply unhappy with the leadership provided by [[Clifford P. Janey]], Vance's successor.{{cite news|last=King|first=Colbert I.|title=A Tale of Two Councils|work=The Washington Post|date=November 25, 2006|page=A21}} It also funded a $400,000 study the same year on behalf of incoming mayor [[Adrian Fenty]] on how to take over the public school system.{{cite news|last=Pearlstein|first=Steven|title=Softening Economy Doesn't Harden Hearts|work=The Washington Post|date=December 21, 2007|page=D1}} Fenty subsequently proposed major legislative changes that gave the mayor far greater power over the DCPS.{{cite news|last1=Nakamura|first1=David|last2=Montgomery|first2=Lori|title=Fenty Poised to Reach For D.C. School Reins|work=The Washington Post|date=September 17, 2006|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Fenty Reverses On Schools|work=The Washington Post|date=December 8, 2006|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Nakamura|first1=David|last2=Haynes|first2=V. Dion|title=Fenty Details Proposal To Take Over Schools|work=The Washington Post|date=January 5, 2007|page=A1}} These were approved by the city council in April 2007 and permitted to become law by the United States Congress.{{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Fenty's School Takeover Approved|work=The Washington Post|date=April 20, 2007|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Senate Approves Fenty's School Takeover Plan|work=The Washington Post|date=May 23, 2007|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Bush Approves Charter Change for Takeover of Schools|work=The Washington Post|date=June 2, 2007|page=B6}} Janney was fired by Mayor [[Adrian Fenty]] on June 12, 2007, and [[Michelle Rhee]] installed as the city's new Chancellor of Public Schools.{{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Fenty To Oust Janey Today|work=The Washington Post|date=June 12, 2007|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Nikita|title=D.C. Council Approves Rhee as Schools Chief|work=The Washington Post|date=July 11, 2007|page=B1}} Certain statements by Rhee were misconstrued by opponents of the school takeover, who said that Rhee had to seek Federal City Council approval of all major city schools policy changes. Although Rhee never made any such statement, the claims gained some traction among some public school activists.{{cite news|last1=Woodlee|first1=Yolanda|last2=Clark|first2=Ashlee|title=Hear the Latest About the Federal City Council?|work=The Washington Post|date=August 9, 2007|page=T1}} But the Federal City Council was, according to ''The Washington Post'' reporter Mike DeBonis, "a prime supporter of Fenty's education reform efforts."{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=$180,000 Raised for D.C. Transfer of Power|work=The Washington Post|date=December 2, 2010|page=B1}} Reform of city finances and government also occupied the Federal City Council. In 2001, at the behest of Natwar M. Gandhi, D.C.'s chief financial officer, the organization agreed to update its 1994 study on city revenues in order to build a consensus in Congress for a restructuring of the District's financing mechanisms.{{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=Downturn Has D.C. Looking For Help|work=The Washington Post|date=November 28, 2001|page=B1}} The report, ''Assessing the District's Financial Position'', released in March 2002, called for a [[commuter tax]]{{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=District Appeals to U.S. For Tax on Commuters|work=The Washington Post|date=March 12, 2002|page=B1}} and restoration of an annual federal payment in lieu of property taxes. The report also warned of half-billion dollar budget deficits if city spending were not slashed and tax cuts deferred.{{cite news|last=Hsu|first=Spencer S.|title=D.C. Deficits On Horizon, Study Finds|work=The Washington Post|date=March 15, 2002|page=B1}} In 2006, the organization raised $100,000 to help incoming chairman of the Council of the District of Columbia, [[Vincent C. Gray]], fund a multiyear strategy plan for council action. It also raised more than $400,000 to help Fenty pay for an improved candidate recruitment process for his mayoral cabinet, and for a study on how to take over the public school system. For the first time since the 1980s, the organization made another major push to improve funding for Metro. In September 2004, the Federal City Council joined with the Board of Trade and the [[Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments]] to create a task force to study Metro's revenues and financing.{{cite news|last1=Layton|first1=Lyndsey|last2=Ginsberg|first2=Steven|title=New Ways Of Funding Metro to Be Explored|work=The Washington Post|date=September 9, 2004|page=B1}} The group proposed that local governments dedicate a portion of their sales tax to Metro, but the plan generated no interest by local or state governments.{{cite news|last=Ginsberg|first=Steven|title=Leaders Find Tax Increase to Aid Metro Unappealing|work=The Washington Post|date=January 1, 2005|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Duggan|first1=Paul|last2=Aratani|first2=Lori|title=Government and Business Officials Push For New Metro Financing System|work=The Washington Post|date=May 30, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/government-and-business-officials-push-for-new-metro-financing-system/2016/05/30/f0eb84d8-234c-11e6-9e7f-57890b612299_story.html}} ===2010s: Narrowed priorities=== [[File:Mayor Williams Anthony.jpg|thumb|Former D.C. Mayor Anthony A. Williams was appointed chief executive officer/executive director of the Federal City Council in 2012.]] In the 2010s, the Federal City Council continued to tackle many small issues in an attempt to improve the livability of Washington, D.C. These included improving the streetscape of 10th Street SW (also known as L'Enfant Promenade),{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=New partnership for SW waterfront|work=The Washington Post|date=May 24, 2010|page=A15}} adding a [[Bus lane|bus-only lane]] and [[tram|streetcar]] to [[K Street (Washington, D.C.)|K Street NW]] in downtown, reopening Pennsylvania Avenue NW near the White House, addressing congestion on downtown streets, improving D.C.'s tourism industry, supporting the 2015 merger between [[Exelon]] and [[Pepco]].{{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Aaron C.|last2=Heath|first2=Thomas|title=Two Sides Target Bowser on Exelon-Pepco Deal|work=The Washington Post|date=September 18, 2015|page=B3|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Davis|first1=Aaron C.|last2=Heath|first2=Thomas|title=D.C. Mayor Reverses Course and Backs Pepco-Exelon Merger|work=The Washington Post|date=September 18, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/dc-mayor-reverses-course-and-backs-pepco-exelon-merger/2015/10/06/15bf2b60-6c5b-11e5-b31c-d80d62b53e28_story.html|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=Exelon Bid to Buy Pepco Gets Boost|work=The Washington Post|date=October 28, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/exelon-bid-to-buy-pepco-gets-boost/2015/10/28/c76353a8-7d83-11e5-beba-927fd8634498_story.html}} In 2011, the Federal City Council began work on a new strategic plan to guide the organization's decision-making. It was the first strategic plan for the organization in more than a decade. The plan identified four key priorities: Lowering unemployment by developing new industries (its top priority), ensuring the city's financial stability and integrity (its second priority), improving public education, and improving city infrastructure. By design, the strategic plan closely tracked the major priorities of newly elected Mayor Vincent C. Gray.{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Shades of Gray at Federal City Council|work=The Washington Post|date=August 12, 2011|page=B2}} In April 2012, the Federal City Council hired former mayor Anthony Williams as its new executive director. He replaced eight-year veteran John W. Hill, Jr. Williams reiterated the organization's focus on jobs, government effectiveness and efficiency, and improvements to infrastructure. Williams' appointment was widely seen by the news media as a significant boost to the organization's influence.{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Nikita|last2=DeBonis|first2=Mike|title=Ex-Mayor to Lead Local Policy Group|work=The Washington Post|date=April 20, 2012|page=B1}} To work toward the goal of lower unemployment, the Federal City Council opposed enactment in 2013 of a "[[living wage]]" law in the District of Columbia.{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Federal City Council, Ralph Nader Wade Into 'living wage' debate|work=The Washington Post|date=August 10, 2013|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/wp/2013/08/09/federal-city-council-ralph-nader-wade-into-living-wage-debate/}} The organization also joined an effort, spearheaded by The 2030 Group, to plan a multi-decade strategy for helping seven key industries in the region grow as well as how to encourage greater economic diversification.{{cite news|last=McCartney|first=Robert|title=Here's how D.C. business thinks region should react to painful sequestration|work=The Washington Post|date=August 29, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/heres-how-dc-business-thinks-region-should-react-to-painful-sequestration/2015/08/29/be5b78dc-4c44-11e5-902f-39e9219e574b_story.html}} Tax issues largely occupied the group's attention when it came to the city's financial stability. The Federal City Council supported a successful city sales tax on gym memberships and yoga classes that generated $5 million a year. The organization backed the "wellness tax" in order to pay for a city council-enacted income tax cut that cost $143 million a year.{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Gym Levy Survives Challenge in D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=June 25, 2014|page=B1}} The Federal City Council also supported the D.C. Tax Revision Commission, and members of the council served on the commission. The commission recommended changes to the District's tax code (including adding a bracket for middle-income earners and an increase in the standard deduction) which made it the second-most [[Progressive tax|progressive]] in the nation.{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Study: D.C.'s tax system is one of America's fairest|work=The Washington Post|date=January 15, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/wp/2015/01/15/study-d-c-s-tax-system-is-one-of-americas-fairest/}} However, the organization also supported a bid to make the District of Columbia the American host-city candidate for the [[2024 Summer Olympics]]. As the Federal City Council saw it, the bid gave the region an opportunity to engage in forward-looking plans that would ensure the region's economic stability by developing infrastructure, transportation, tourism, cultural facilities, and sporting venues that would last for 30 to 40 years.{{cite news|last=Ramsey|first=W. Russell|title=D.C. Can Still Gain From the 2024 Games Bid|work=The Washington Post|date=March 1, 2015|page=C4}} The Federal City Council was active on a much wider range of infrastructure initiatives. It advocated in 2012 creation of a public-private investment trust fund to help rebuild and improve the city's parks, public transit system, and sewer system. It established an internal task force to identify new means of financing bridge improvement, repair, and replacement; a new city jail; and improvements to city-owned golf courses. In 2013, the organization announced the creation of the Anacostia Waterfront Trust to coordinate regional efforts to end the continuing pollution of the [[Anacostia River]] and to begin cleanup efforts of the riverbed. Doug Siglin, formerly the federal affairs director for the [[Chesapeake Bay Foundation]], was named executive director of the Trust. The Federal City Council agreed to back a multibillion-dollar federal plan to end raw sewage flows into the river; mitigation of [[greywater]], [[surface runoff]], and [[urban runoff]] into the river; and research into the best way to address the deep deposits of dangerous contaminants on the river bottom.{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Anacostia River Is Federal City Council's Newest Focus|work=The Washington Post|date=October 28, 2013|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/wp/2013/10/28/anacostia-river-is-federal-city-councils-newest-focus/}}{{cite news|last=Pipkin|first=Whitney|title=D.C.'s 'Forgotten River' Getting Some Attention|work=Bay Journal|date=March 11, 2014|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=http://www.bayjournal.com/article/d.c.s_forgotten_river_getting_some_attention}} As part of its Anacostia River initiative, the council supported legislation (enacted in 2014) banning the use of [[polystyrene]] foam containers for use by [[Take-out|food carryout]] providers.{{cite news|last=Flaherty|first=Mary Pat|title=D.C. Mayor Signs Bill Banning Plastic Foam Food and Drink Containers for Carryout Use|work=The Washington Post|date=July 30, 2014|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/dc-mayor-signs-bill-banning-plastic-foam-food-and-drink-containers-for-carryout-use/2014/07/29/7468bf86-1762-11e4-9349-84d4a85be981_story.html}} It also continued work to preserve and improve Union Station,{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=Former Mayor Williams Pushes for Public-Private Partnerships for D.C. Infrastructure|work=The Washington Post|date=December 7, 2012|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/former-mayor-williams-pushes-for-public-private-partnerships-for-dc-infrastructure/2012/12/07/dbd69d64-3efb-11e2-bca3-aadc9b7e29c5_story.html}}{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=The State of the Union|work=The Washington Post|date=April 9, 2012|page=A15}} and worked closely with the Union Station Redevelopment Corporation, Amtrak, the U.S. Department of Transportation, and local real estate developer [[Akridge]] to begin work on Burnham Place—a $1.5 billion [[Mixed-use development|mixed-use]] development that will build a new passenger terminal and retail, residential, and office buildings over the tracks (while adding a large parking garage beneath the tracks). This included studying the infrastructure and architectural/engineering aspects of Union Station and identifying as many sources for funding and financing as possible.{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=This Could Be D.C.'s Next Hot Neighborhood, But Building It Won't Be Easy—Or Cheap|work=The Washington Post|date=September 13, 2014|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/this-could-be-dcs-next-hot-neighborhood-but-building-itwont-be-easy----or-cheap/2014/09/12/0cfea4ac-3790-11e4-8601-97ba88884ffd_story.html}} From 2010 to 2015, the Federal City Council remained largely quiet on issues facing Metro and [[DC Streetcar]], however.{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=Public Transit On The Ropes|work=The Washington Post|date=March 3, 2015|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/digger/wp/2015/03/03/public-transit-on-the-ropes/}} However, the organization did undertake a study of Metro in 2015 which led to a November 2016 report that called for a federal takeover of the transit agency if its three state-level partners did not agree to radically reconstitute Metro's governance structure. The report called for Metro's board to be drastically reduced in number and to be composed of transit professionals rather than political appointees. It also called for weaker protections for Metro's [[trade union]]s, and for each state-level partner to adopt a dedicated tax to support Metro's capital needs and operations. The Federal City Council said it would attempt to build a coalition, consisting primarily of the region's largest employers and businesses with the most revenue, to support the changes.{{cite news|last=McCartney|first=Robert|title=How to Salvage Metro? Rewrite the Compact, Says Influential D.C. Business Group|work=The Washington Post|date=November 19, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/how-to-salvage-metro-rewrite-the-compact-says-influential-dc-business-group/2016/11/19/c703ac3a-adb3-11e6-8b45-f8e493f06fcd_story.html}} Within two weeks, the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments and the Greater Washington Board of Trade had signed on to the proposals.{{cite news|last=McCartney|first=Robert|title=There Are Four Proposals to Save Metro. Which Might Prevail?|work=The Washington Post|date=November 29, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/there-are-four-proposals-to-save-metro-which-could-prevail/2016/11/28/489fdf0e-b1b8-11e6-8616-52b15787add0_story.html}} The state of Virginia agreed to back the idea of a smaller, more professional board. The Federal City Council was somewhat inactive on education reform for the first half of the 2010s. It quietly supported the education reforms planned and implemented by public schools Chancellor Michelle Rhee and her successor, [[Kaya Henderson]].{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=Muriel Bowser Wins Endorsement From Former D.C. Mayor Anthony Williams|work=The Washington Post|date=July 4, 2014|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/muriel-bowser-wins-endorsement-from-former-dc-mayor-anthony-williams/2014/07/03/b0c43000-02d1-11e4-8572-4b1b969b6322_story.html}} The council first drew media attention in 2016, when the organization's executive director agreed to co-chair a mayoral panel studying improvements to the city's public and charter schools. By 2016, the Federal City Council had expanded on its strategic plan by agreeing conduct more research into the city's problems, as well as act as a lobbyist for business before the Council of the District of Columbia. Lobbying came to the forefront due to the formation in 2001 of the [[DC Fiscal Policy Institute]], a [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] [[think tank]] focused on local issues founded by the left-leaning [[Center on Budget and Policy Priorities]]. As part of its lobbying effort, the Federal City Council sent representatives on a trade mission to [[China]] and worked to defeat a proposed [[Parental leave|paid family leave]] bill.{{cite news|last=O'Connell|first=Jonathan|title=Back In Spotlight, Former D.C. Mayor Tony Williams Pushes Pro-Business Agenda|work=The Washington Post|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/tony-williams-wants-a-word-with-the-dc-council/2016/03/04/972ddb7e-dc0e-11e5-81ae-7491b9b9e7df_story.html}} ==Projects== On several occasions, the Federal City Council has created subsidiary organizations to take on tasks of a specific geographic or technical nature. Some of these have proven highly influential in themselves. Short-term initiatives include a 1963 effort to demolish temporary building on the National Mall, a 1988 task force to win federal approval for the construction of an international trade center, the early 1990s Downtown Interactive Task Force, a 2002 effort to lobby the federal government for more money for the District of Columbia (led by Robert G. Liberatore, a senior vice president at [[DaimlerChrysler]]), and a 2012 working group to identify new means of financing infrastructure. The Federal City Council has, on occasion, created longer-lived, semi-permanent or permanent subsidiaries or organizations as well. ===Downtown Progress=== The first longer-term project initiated by the Federal City Council was Downtown Progress. In 1958, the Federal City Council recommended the creation of a new organization to attract business investment in the former retail core of the District of Columbia.{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=93}} On April 1, 1960, this organization, the National Capital Downtown Committee, Inc.—better known as "Downtown Progress"—was formed as a joint effort of the Federal City Council and a federal agency, the [[National Capital Planning Commission]].{{sfn|Derthick|1962|page=200}} Knox Banner was Downtown Progress' long-time leader.{{cite news|last=Pearson|first=Richard|title=Knox Banner, Key Figure in Efforts to Revitalize Downtown D.C., Dies|work=The Washington Post|date=April 11, 1994|page=D4}} The group, which represented primarily very large businesses, produced a number of extensive, expensive plans to redevelop downtown D.C. and build an extensive network of subway lines beneath the area.{{cite news|last=Haggerty|first=Mary Ann|title=The Place That Lost Its Heart|work=The Washington Post|date=September 4, 1995|page=WBIZ12}} The organization helped to win the creation of the Washington Metro, and development of the Washington Convention Center. It was not successful, however, in pushing for a similar network of underground tunnels and roadways that would accommodate rapid-transit buses and truck delivery. Downtown Progress also worked closely with the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation to develop plans for the [[Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site#Rejuvenation|restoration and redevelopment of Pennsylvania Avenue NW]] in the 1960s and 1970s, and worked with the [[National Park Service]] to restore [[Ford's Theatre]] in 1968. ===Municipal Research Bureau=== The second long-term organization created by the Federal City Council was the Municipal Research Bureau. Created in 1974, it was led by Philip M. Dearborn, Jr., an expert in municipal finance and director of the Brookings Institution's Greater Washington Research Program. Its mission was to provide general research on issues important to the District of Columbia.{{cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|title=Philip Dearborn Dies; City Finance Expert|work=The Washington Post|date=August 24, 2002|page=B6}} It merged with the Washington Center for Metropolitan Studies in 1978 to become the Greater Washington Research Center.{{cite news|last=Engel|first=Margaret|title=Think Tank Emerges as an Influential Voice In the D.C. Area|work=The Washington Post|date=November 21, 1982|accessdate=December 13, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1982/11/21/think-tank-emerges-as-a-influential-voice-in-the-dc-area/7177ae65-9dd0-414c-b496-d4e5bfe37b4b/}} The Greater Washington Research Center merged with the Brookings Institution in 2001. ===The Economic Club=== In 1986, the Federal City Council spawned the [[Economic Club of Washington]]. The group formed in response to the nationalization and globalization of many D.C. businesses, as well as the rapid increase in "[[new economy]]" businesses inside the city and in the surrounding suburbs. There was a sense that many of the area's mid- and top-level managers were not from the area, felt little attachment to the region, and had few friends in the city.{{cite news|last=Bhattarai|first=Abha|title=A Quarter-Century of Big Names In Business|work=The Washington Post|date=June 4, 2012|page=A19}} The Economic Club was founded by Federal City Council members Ed Hoffman (president of [[Woodward & Lothrop]]) and R. Robert Linowes (a successful local attorney).
