The goal was two-fold: First, to provide a way for business leaders to socialize, become acquainted with one another, and form a sense of community; second, to expose its members to new thinking and ideas in the realm of economics.{{cite news|last=Irwin|first=Neil|title=Economic Club of Washington Attracts New Generation of Movers, Shakers|work=The Washington Post|date=May 31, 2004|page=E1}} The group has since become "a cornerstone of the Washington business community", largely on the basis of its ability to bring a group of top-level business leaders together to listen to policymakers. (It does not advocate for, lobby on behalf of, or speak for the business community.) ===Committee on Public Education=== D.C. Committee on Public Education (a group of parents and business, religious, and civic leaders), in 1988. When released on June 20, 1989, the report recommended spending $355 million over the next five years to extend the school day by five hours (to a 7 A.M. to 6 P.M. schedule); extend the school year by 40 days; construct new schools; repair existing schools; and add stronger math and science programs and multicultural education to the curriculum. To pay for the plan, the Federal City Council's team suggested cutting administrative costs by $8.5 million, eliminating 400 central staff positions, closing some schools, and selling some school property. The Committee on Public Education remained active for many years, issuing reports critical of the public school system. ===Agenda Progress and D.C. Agenda=== Another major project of the Federal City Council was Agenda Progress. This project came about in 1991 after former President [[Jimmy Carter]] asked members of the Federal City Council whether they believed their efforts would completely turn the city around in five to ten years. None did. Agenda Process was launched shortly after Carter's speech as a means to identify projects and mechanisms that would meet the challenge Carter set for the group. Agenda Progress spent 1993 and 1994 cooperating with the Brookings Institution on a study of the finances of the District of Columbia. This study deeply influenced the Clinton administration's decision to impose the [[District of Columbia Financial Control Board]] on the city in 1995. In 1995, Agenda Progress was renamed D.C. Agenda, and led by former Barry administration official James O. Gibson. Its original purpose was to serve as an unofficial transition committee at the start of Marion Barry's fourth term (1995 to 1999) as mayor. It represented the interests of large corporations and nonprofits doing business with city, providing them with research and technical assistance. In time, D.C. Agenda shifted its focus to building coalitions to support its agenda on city governance and financial/tax reform, improved support for economic development, neighborhood redevelopment, and at-risk youth intervention.{{sfn|Barras|1998|page=164}}{{cite news|last=Fuller|first=Nicole|title=DC Agenda Disbands As Funding Dwindles|work=The Washington Post|date=August 5, 2004|page=DE3}} In some cases, D.C. Agenda mimicked or implemented city functions and acted as a liaison with corporations or nonprofits to implement public policy. D.C. Agenda also had a subsidiary body, the D.C. Agenda Support Corporation, led by former District of Columbia Administrator Carol Thompson Cole.{{sfn|Barras|1998|page=164}} D.C. Agenda had several subcommittees as well, including an Economic Development Strategy Group (organized in 1996 and led by local attorney Dana Stebbins). In 1997, D.C. Agenda proposed creating a nonprofit, tax-exempt, public-private economic development corporation. The organization, dominated by private developers, would have broad power (including [[Eminent domain in the United States|eminent domain]] and the right to own property) to direct planning and engage in redevelopment of the city's downtown and business corridors. The proposal asked for $50 million in cash from the federal government (with 40 percent earmarked for redevelopment efforts by other nonprofits), and $250 million in redistributable tax credits and surplus federal property.{{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title=D.C.'s Public and Private Sectors Finally May Be Ready to Dance|work=The Washington Post|date=May 22, 1997|page=E3}} The D.C. Agenda proposal became the [[National Capital Revitalization Corp.]],{{cite news|last=Behr|first=Peter|title=D.C. Development Plan Wins Broad Support|work=The Washington Post|date=February 3, 1998|page=D5}} which was created by law adopted by the [[Council of the District of Columbia]] in April 1998.{{cite news|last1=Loeb|first1=Vernon|last2=Wilgoren|first2=Debbi|title=Council's Plan to Hand Over Economic Development Powers Criticized|work=The Washington Post|date=March 12, 1998|page=J1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Pyatt|first=Rudolph A., Jr.|title='Cowboy Capitalism' Allegations Overshadow D.C. Revitalization Measure|work=The Washington Post|date=June 25, 1998|page=C3}} D.C. Agenda created the nonprofit D.C. Children and Youth Investment Trust Corporation in 1999.{{cite news|last=Davis|first=Aaron C.|title=Mismanagement Has Bankrupted a D.C. Nonprofit, Endangering Programs For At-Risk Youths, Board Members Say|work=The Washington Post|date=April 26, 2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/mismanagement-has-bankrupted-a-dc-nonprofit-endangering-programs-for-at-risk-youth-board-members-say/2016/04/26/51f4a51c-0bb4-11e6-bfa1-4efa856caf2a_story.html}} The trust worked to obtain government and corporate grants to help at-risk youth and build after-school programs at city public schools. After several years of mismanagement, the trust collapsed and dissolved in April 2016.{{Efn|In 2007, D.C. Council member [[Harry Thomas, Jr.]] embezzle more than $350,000 from the trust and was sentenced to more than three years in prison. After the scandal, the trust struggled to obtain new funding. In 2013, a congressional investigation found that the trust lacked financial controls to properly account for its expenditures, which included administering the city's $20 million school voucher program.}} In 2000, D.C. Agenda began collecting funds from the public as part of a political campaign to support a [[referendum]] that would dramatically alter the powers of the D.C. State Board of Education. More than $80,000 was collected from 25 individuals. But the [[District of Columbia Office of Campaign Finance]] found that D.C. Agenda had failed to register as a [[political action committee]], as required by law. D.C. Agenda president John H. McKoy{{Efn|McCoy was a former executive at Lockheed Martin IMS, a former director of the District of Columbia Office of Planning, a former executive vice president of the [[Anacostia Waterfront Corporation]], and director of programmatic initiatives at the nonprofit Fight for Children.}} agreed to return all the funds to avoid a fine.{{cite news|last=Woodlee|first=Yolanda|title=D.C. Group Pushing School Board Change Hits Campaign Snag|work=The Washington Post|date=June 18, 2000|page=C4}} D.C. Agenda dissolved in May 2004 after failing to raise the $1.7 million a year its annual budget required.{{Efn|D.C. Agenda drew its funding from grants provided by several national and local foundations, corporations, and the local and federal government.}} Several of the organization's subsidiary efforts, such as the Neighborhood Information Service, the Morris and Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation Awards, and Neighborhood College, were transferred to other nonprofits in the area.{{Efn|The Neighborhood Information Service collected a wide range of economic, social, demographic, and other information on the District's 131 neighborhoods, and distributed this information free to neighborhood leaders. The Cafritz Foundation Awards recognized city employees for exceptional service. Neighborhood College was a free program which educated neighborhood leaders about the history and current socio-economic status of their neighborhoods.}} ===Washington, DC Police Foundation=== The Washington, DC Police Foundation (also known as the National Capital Police Fund) is a grant-making arm of the Federal City Council which provides grants to the [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia]] (MPD). According to the Federal City Council, the foundation was created in 2000.{{cite web|title=Our History|website=Federal City Council|date=2016|accessdate=December 15, 2016|url=http://www.federalcitycouncil.org/history}} It made a $10,000 grant to the MPD in 2004 to purchase stolen goods tracking software,{{cite news|last=Wilber|first=Del Quentin|title=D.C. Cracks Down as Stolen-Goods Dealers Evolve|work=The Washington Post|date=August 16, 2004|page=A1}} and a $30,000 grant in 2005 to allow the MPD to purchase automobiles with [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] tags for use as "bait cars".{{cite news|last=Wilber|first=Del Quentin|title=Inefficiency Plagues Program to Curb D.C. Auto Thefts|work=The Washington Post|date=August 21, 2005|page=C1}} It is unclear how the foundation generates its income. ===Anacostia Waterfront Trust=== In October 2013, the Federal City Council established a new nonprofit, the Anacostia Waterfront Trust, to coordinated regional and federal efforts to prevent the dumping of raw sewage and toxic materials into the Anacostia River, and to research ways in how best to handle the contaminants already on the riverbed. The organization began researching the history of [[Anacostia Park]] in 2016, in an attempt to identify past plans for the park. The effort was a prelude to beginning an effort to craft a strategic vision for the park that would allow for its sustainable development.{{cite news|last=Kobell|first=Rona|title=Anacostia Park, once planned as an urban oasis, still more of a mirage|work=Bay Journal|date=May 25, 2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.bayjournal.com/article/anacostia_park_once_planned_as_an_urban_oasis_still_more_of_a_mirage}} The Trust also supported the D.C. government's plan for trading "stormwater retention credits" (similar to [[carbon credit]]s) among businesses in an effort to reduce low-quality runoff into the Anacostia.{{cite news|last=Day|first=Jeff|title=DC ready to ramp up its stormwater trading program|work=Bay Journal|date=September 28, 2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.bayjournal.com/article/dc_ready_to_ramp_up_its_stormwater_retention_trading_program}} ==About the Federal City Council== ===Influence=== The Federal City Council is highly influential in [[real estate development]] and [[urban planning]] issues in the District of Columbia.{{sfn|Fauntroy|2003|page=46}} It is the Federal City Council's focus on construction and development that, according to ''The Washington Post'' reporter David Leonhardt, has allowed the organization to be at the forefront in promoting "almost every major downtown development project since World War II", including Southwest urban renewal, the entire Washington Metro, the Pennsylvania Avenue Development Corporation, the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center, and the renovation of Union Station.{{cite news|last=Irwin|first=Neil|title=Monday Morning|work=The Washington Post|date=September 27, 2004|page=F2}} In the late 1960s through the late 1970s, ''The Washington Post'' said, the organization "sometimes carried more clout on Capitol Hill than the District's political leadership." ''Post'' columnist Colbert I. King said its power rivaled that of the city council in 2006, while ''Post'' reporters Marc Fisher and Valerie Strauss in 1997 said the group consisted of "Washington's corporate and governmental elite".{{cite news|last1=Fisher|first1=Marc|last2=Strauss|first2=Valerie|title=Born on Heels of Rights Movement, University Kept Marching in Place|work=The Washington Post|date=January 16, 1997|page=A1}} Mark Bisnow of the ''Washington Business Journal'' called the Federal City Council "the most important organization in Washington you've never heard of" in 2005 and ''Post'' reporter Mike DeBonis described it as "the city's ultimate conglomeration of economic power". ''Post'' reporter Jerry Knight called the organization "self-appointed...business Brahmins" in 1989,{{cite news|last=Knight|first=Jerry|title=Business Rethinks Barry|work=The Washington Post|date=March 13, 1989|page=WBIZ34}} while Colbert I. King said in 2007 that the Federal City Council was synonymous with the Washington establishment. In 2012, however, ''The Washington Post'' business columnist [[Steven Pearlstein]] argued that the Federal City Council lost much of its influence in the first decade of the 21st century. He argued that, in part, the organization was a victim of its success, having accomplished most of its goals. This has allowed members of the organization to turn their attention elsewhere. He also asserted it lacked effective and visionary leadership, that globalization of local businesses had robbed the organization of support, that excessive partisanship at the federal and state levels make progress nearly impossible, and that many of the problems now confronting the city are regional in nature.{{cite news|last=Pearlstein|first=Steven|title=What Washington Needs Now? An Old-Fashioned Business Cabal|work=The Washington Post|date=January 22, 2012|page=G2}} Its members admit to being self-interested and looking out for their own interests, but claim they do so only to make the city more livable. The group has also been criticized for ignoring the views of residents affected by Federal City Council projects, of lacking accountability, and pursuing an agenda at odds with those of the public. ===Avoiding press attention=== The Federal City Council has a longstanding unofficial policy of avoiding press attention and publicity,{{Efn|''The Washington Post'' has consistently supported the Federal City Council's projects in its editorial pages.}} although in 2016 executive director Anthony Williams said that the group would be implementing some incremental changes to its policy of avoiding the press. The group's media-avoidance policy has been characterized in various ways. ''[[The Economist]]'' described it in 1988 as a "select and shadowy gathering of some of the city's top business and professional people", "[o]perating on the old-boy network". In 1997, reporter Bradford McKee called the organization "secretive" and "a shadow chamber of commerce and phantom government..."{{sfn|McKee|1997|pages=48-49}} In 2014, Jonathan O'Connell at ''The Washington Post'' called it "historically insular". Other descriptions of the group's publicity shyness have been more positive. ''Washington Post'' columnist Colbert I. King has dismissed theories that the organization is "a clandestine outfit", noting it merely "work[s] quietly behind the scenes on city issues". This view is echoed by ''Post'' reporters Yolanda Woodlee and Ashlee Clark. ''Post'' business columnist Steven Pearlstein has argued that the organization's avoidance of publicity has been one of the reasons it has been so successful. ===Membership=== The Federal City Council is a private, nonprofit organization of business people, civic leaders, former federal executive branch officials, and local and federal politicians.{{sfn|Barras|1998|page=164}} Membership in the organization is by invitation only. Members are known as "trustees", and the membership group is known as the Board of Washington Trustees.{{cite news|title=Names in the News|work=The Washington Post|date=July 29, 2004|page=T6}} The ''Washington Business Journal'' says the organization declines to identify its members. However, as of December 2016 the organization provides the names of about 225 trustees and "trustee emeritus" on its Web site.{{cite web|title=Trustees|website=Federal City Council|date=2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.federalcitycouncil.org/trustees}} The Federal City Council's members include some of the city's wealthiest{{cite news|last1=Irwin|first1=Neil|last2=Woodlee|first2=Yolanda|title=10.3 Acres of Tantalizing Potential in D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=October 16, 2003|page=B1}} and most civic-minded businesspeople. The members have been described as the representative of the city's "business elite"{{cite news|last=Fisher|first=Marc|title=District No Joke Now|work=The Washington Post|date=October 26, 2011|page=A1}} and the organization as the "key business voice" in the city. Reports of the number of members have varied over time. ''The Washington Post'' said it had either 100 or 137 members in 1975, 150 members in 1994, 150 members in 2000 and 2002,{{cite news|last1=Timberg|first1=Craig|last2=Leonnig|first2=Carol D.|title=As Barry Plots Another Comeback, Williams Keeps His Thoughts to Himself|work=The Washington Post|date=March 21, 2002|page=T2}} 190 members in 2002, more than 250 members in 2003, 194 members in 2004,{{Efn|These were mostly white men. The organization had 31 African Americans and two women as members in 2004}} either 170 or 180 members in 2011, and 170 members in 2012. As of 2003, the Federal City Council and the Washington Board of Trade shared many members, [[George Mason University]] professor Michael K. Fauntroy characterized the Federal City Council as "more of an elitist group than the Board".{{sfn|Fauntroy|2003|pages=46-47}} As late as 1994, the Federal City Council's membership was overwhelmingly white. Terence C. Golden, the organization's chairman in 2004, admitted, "This was basically a white man's business organization in a city that was very divided". The Federal City Council at one point had an ''ex officio'' class of membership. These individuals include people such as [[Cabinet of the United States|Cabinet]] secretaries and local university presidents. As of 1994, there were about 50 ex-officio members. ===Governance, presidents, and chairmen=== Leadership of the Federal City Council consists of a president and a chairman of the Washington Board of Trustees. A presidential term is one year. A president may succeed him or her self, there are no term limits, and most presidents serve several years. The board meets twice a year. The chairman is assisted by a vice chairman. Additional officers include a [[Secretary (title)|secretary]]; [[treasurer]]; two vice presidents; vice presidents for federal relations, membership, membership engagement, nominations, and strategic planning; a [[general counsel]]; and the chief executive officer/executive director. The board elects 28 members to serve on an executive committee, which meets monthly and governs the organization between board meetings. ''Ex officio'' members of the executive committee (who have no voting rights) include the chairs of the Federal City Council's standing committees and task forces, the chair of the Greater Washington Board of Trade, and the chair of the D.C. Chamber of Commerce.{{cite web|title=Executive Committee|website=Federal City Council|date=2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.federalcitycouncil.org/executive-committee}} In 1958, the organization established a "national advisory board" consisting of individuals who may have once lived in Washington, D.C., or who have a strong interest in the city but do not live there. These individuals were often former members of Congress, former executive branch department heads, or corporate executives. This body apparently no longer exists. A partial list of the presidents of the Federal City Council includes: # George A. Garrett - November 1954 to December 1961{{Efn|Garrett was [[United States Ambassador to Ireland|United States Minister to Ireland]] from April 10, 1947, to March 16, 1950. The position was then upgraded to Ambassador on March 17, 1950, and Garrett continued to serve as Ambassador until May 27, 1951.}} # [[Gordon Gray (politician)|Gordon Gray]] - January 1962 to 1963{{cite news|last=Hailey|first=Albon B.|title=Gray Elected to Federal Council Post|work=The Washington Post|date=January 9, 1962|page=A1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Smith|first=J.Y.|title=Gordon Gray, Former Secretary Of U.S. Army, Dies at Age 73|work=The Washington Post|date=November 27, 1982|page=B4}}{{Efn|Gray was [[United States Secretary of the Army]] from 1949 to 1950 under President [[Harry S. Truman]] and [[National Security Advisor (United States)|National Security Advisor]] from 1958 to 1961 under President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]].}} # [[William P. Rogers]] - September 1963 to September 1965{{cite news|title=Federal City Council Elects William Rogers|work=The Washington Post|date=October 1, 1963|page=B1}}{{cite news|title=Federal City Council Elected|work=The Washington Post|date=September 30, 1970|page=D9}}{{Efn|Rogers was [[United States Attorney General]] from October 23, 1957, to January 20, 1961.}} # [[Stephen Ailes]] - September 1965 to September 1970{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Bart|title=Stephen Ailes Dies|work=The Washington Post|date=July 6, 2001|page=B6}}{{Efn|Ailes was [[United States Secretary of the Army]] from January 28, 1964, to July 1, 1965.}} # [[George C. McGhee]] - September 1970 to 1974{{Efn|McGhee was a career diplomat who served as [[United States Ambassador to Turkey]]; [[Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern, South Asian, and African Affairs]]; [[Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs]]; and [[United States Ambassador to West Germany]].}} # [[Sol Linowitz]] - 1974 to September 1978{{cite news|last=Whitaker|first=Joseph D.|title=New Housing Called Prime Need in D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=September 30, 1975|page=C1}}{{cite news|last=Lynton|first=Stephen J.|title=Former OMB Chief Is Named Federal City Council Head|work=The Washington Post|date=September 26, 1978|page=B3}}{{Efn|Linowitz was chairman of [[Xerox]] from 1961 to 1965, co-negotiated the [[Torrijos–Carter Treaties]] in 1977, and was President [[Jimmy Carter]]'s Middle East peace negotiators from 1979 to 1981.}} # [[James Thomas Lynn|James T. Lynn]] - September 1978 to September 1983{{cite news|last=Eisen|first=Jack|title=Federal City Council Change|work=The Washington Post|date=October 8, 1983|page=B2}}{{Efn|Lynn was [[United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development|Secretary of Housing and Urban Development]] from 1973 to 1975.}} # [[Harry McPherson]] - September 1983 to September 1990{{cite news|last=Bernstein|first=Adam|title=Key adviser to LBJ became a prominent D.C. lobbyist|work=The Washington Post|date=February 18, 2012|page=B1}}{{Efn|McPherson was Special Assistant and Counsel to the President, and then Special Counsel to the President, in the [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] administration from 1966 to 1969.}} # [[Ann McLaughlin Korologos|Ann Dore McLaughlin]] - September 1990 to September 1995{{cite news|title=Your Money: Movers and Shakers|work=The Washington Times|date=January 29, 1991|page=D2}}{{Efn|McLaughlin (now divorced and remarried, using the name Ann McLaughlin Korologos) was an Under Secretary of the Department of the Interior and Under Secretary of the Department of the Treasury, and was [[United States Secretary of Labor]] from 1987 to 1989.}} # [[Tom Foley]] - September 1995 to September 1998{{cite news|last=King|first=Colbert I.|title=Fred, Did We Really Know You?|work=The Washington Post|date=September 8, 2007|page=A15|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Order in the House — and the Garage|work=Washington Business Journal|date=June 30, 1997|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/1997/06/30/tidbits.html}}{{Efn|Foley was a representative from [[Washington state]] from 1965 to 1995, and [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives]] from 1989 to 1995.}} # [[Bob Dole]] - September 1998 to 2002{{cite news|last=Roman|first=Dave|title=Dole Remains a Winner Despite Most-Notable Loss|work=Florida Times-Union|date=December 3, 1997|accessdate=December 10, 2013|url=http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/120397/2b1Roman.html|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Trescott|first=Jacqueline|title=Music Museum Proposed for D.C.|work=The Washington Post|date=July 9, 1998|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Resnick|first=Amy B.|title=D.C. Mayor-Elect Williams Chooses Politically Connected Transition Team|work=The Bond Buyer|date=November 13, 1998|page=3|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Woodlee|first1=Yolanda|last2=Hsu|first2=Spencer|last3=Thomas-Lester|first3=Avis|title=Transition Grumbling|work=The Washington Post|date=November 19, 1998|page=DC1}}{{cite news|last=Clymer|first=Adam|title=Senator and Delegate Back Plan to Reopen Pennsylvania Avenue|work=The New York Times|date=September 26, 2000|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/26/us/senator-and-delegate-back-plan-to-reopen-pennsylvania-avenue.html}}{{Efn|Dole was the U.S. Senator from Kansas from 1969 to 1996, and Senate Majority Leader from 1985 to 1985, and again from 1995 to 1996.}} # [[Fred Thompson]] - November 2002 to October 2005{{cite news|title=Metro: In Brief|work=The Washington Post|date=November 26, 2002|page=B3}}{{cite news|title=Fred Thompson takes on federal council role|work=The Knoxville News-Sentinel|date=December 1, 2002|page=H3}}{{Efn|Thompson was a well-known actor, and a senator from Tennessee from 1994 to 2003.}} # [[Frank Keating]] - October 2005 to November 2012{{cite news|title=Local Briefing|work=The Washington Post|date=October 31, 2005|page=D2}}{{Efn|Keating was [[Governor of Oklahoma]] from 1995 to 2003.}} # [[Thomas M. Davis]] - December 2012 to present{{cite news|last=Heath|first=Thomas|title=Federal City Council Has New Leadership|work=The Washington Post|date=December 10, 2012|page=A2}}{{Efn|Davis represented Virginia in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1995 to 2008.}} The chairmanship of the board of directors turns over frequently. As of 2016,{{cite web|title=Officers|website=Federal City Council|date=2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.federalcitycouncil.org/officers}} the chairman was Robert J. Flanagan, construction (Clark Enterprises) and investment (CNF Investments) executive first elected on December 3, 2012. Past chairmen include [[Washington Gas]] executive Donald S. Bittinger;{{cite news|title=D.C. Civic Unit Elects Bittinger As Chairman|work=The Washington Post|date=October 2, 1973|page=D9|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|title=Donald S. Bittinger, 77|work=The Washington Post|date=January 4, 1987|page=B5}} and [[Riggs Bank]] chairmen Vincent C. Burke{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=Patricia|title=Vincent C. Burke Jr., 86|work=The Washington Post|date=January 1, 2009|page=B5}} and Lewellyn Jennings;{{cite news|last=Pearson|first=Richard|title=Lewellyn Jennings Dies|work=The Washington Post|date=May 25, 1983|page=C8}} hotel executive Terence C. Golden, and construction executive Linda Rabbitt. The vice chairman as of 2016 was hotel executive W. Edward Walter. ===Budget and other staff=== Although funding for the Federal City Council is not clear, its budget is substantial. Its fiscal 2014 budget was $2.2 million, up from $1.5 million in fiscal 2013. As of April 2012, the news media reported that the Federal City Council had a small staff of just five people{{cite news|last=Switzky|first=Bryant Ruiz|title=Anthony Williams to Head Federal City Council|work=Washington Business Journal|date=April 19, 2012|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/news/2012/04/19/anthony-williams-to-head-federal-city.html}} (up from four staff in 1994). However, the organization's Web site lists 11 staff (including two who work for the Anacostia Waterfront Trust). Its internal staff structure is not clear, and there have been many title changes over the years. The organization's day-to-day operations are overseen by a chief executive officer/executive director. Chief executive officers/executive directors have included: *G. Yates Cook - 1954 to 1974{{cite news|title=Yates Cook Lauded on Retirement|work=The Washington Post|date=January 22, 1975|page=A4}} *Kenneth R. Sparks - 1974 to September 2004{{cite news|last=Switzky|first=Bryant Ruiz|title=John Hill to Resign From Federal City Council After Eight Years|work=Washington Business Journal|date=October 21, 2011|accessdate=November 27, 2013|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/print-edition/2011/10/21/john-hill-to-resign-from-federal-city.html|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Irwin|first=Neil|title=Peck's Duality: Grow, Preserve|work=The Washington Post|date=October 29, 2001|page=E1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last1=Irwin|first1=Neil|last2=Hedgpeth|first2=Dana|title=Turnover at the Top of Area Business Groups|work=The Washington Post|date=December 19, 2005|page=D1}} *John W. Hill, Jr. - October 2004 to June 2012{{cite news|last=Madigan|first=Sean|title=Hill to Head Federal City Council|work=Washington Business Journal|date=May 17, 2004|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/2004/05/17/daily7.html}}{{Efn|Hill was executive director of the [[District of Columbia Financial Control Board]] from its inception in 1995 to 1999, chief executive of the charity In2Books, and chairman of the board of directors of the [[District of Columbia Public Library]].{{cite news|last=Irwin|first=Neil|title=The Makings of a Museum|work=The Washington Post|date=June 28, 2004|page=E1}}{{cite news|last=Resnick|first=Amy B.|title=D.C. Reformer Looks Back|work=The Bond Buyer|date=April 22, 1999|page=1}}{{cite news|last=DeBonis|first=Mike|title=John Hill to step down at Federal City Council|work=The Washington Post|date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=November 27, 2013|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/mike-debonis/post/john-hill-to-step-down-at-federal-city-council/2011/10/19/gIQABptKyL_blog.html}} He earned $396,000 in 2010 as executive director of the Federal City Council.}} *[[Anthony A. Williams]] - July 2012 to present (as of November 2016){{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Nikita|last2=DeBonis|first2=Mike|title=Former D.C. Mayor Williams to Lead Federal City Council|work=The Washington Post|date=April 19, 2012|accessdate=November 27, 2013|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/former-mayor-anthony-a-williams-to-head-federal-city-council/2012/04/19/gIQAvA5nTT_story.html}} Michael F. Brimmer served as its deputy executive director from 1975 to 1985.{{cite news|title=Md., Va. Entrepreneurs Honored by SBA|work=The Washington Post|date=May 13, 1985|page=W5}} He was followed by David Perry, who served from 1985 to about 2005.{{cite news|title=Minus Olympics, Project Timelines Slow|work=The Washington Post|date=October 3, 2002|page=DE3|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=Bosworth|first=Sharon|title=David Perry to Lead Barracks Row Main Street|work=Hill Rag|date=November 2, 2013|accessdate=December 10, 2013|url=http://www.capitalcommunitynews.com/content/david-perry-lead-barracks-row-main-street}} Other staff include a [[chief operating officer]],{{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Fenty Deputy Backs Shift in Supervision|work=The Washington Post|date=November 17, 2006|page=B4}}{{Efn|Victor A. Reinoso joined the Federal City Council in 2003 as director of education projects, working on school reform. He was elected a member of the D.C. State Board of Education in 2004. He was named the Federal City Council's chief operating officer in 2006,{{cite news|last=Nakamura|first=David|title=Reinoso Faces a Political Gantlet|work=The Washington Post|date=May 6, 2007|page=C1}} and left the organization in January 2007 after being named deputy mayor for education by Mayor Adrian Fenty. As of November 2016, the chief operating officer was Kevin Clinton.{{cite news|last=McCartney|first=Robert|title=Millennial Voters Help Push D.C. Council to the Left, Ousting Old-School Politicians|work=The Washington Post|date=November 1, 2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/2016/11/01/61fe9c0a-9c7e-11e6-a0ed-ab0774c1eaa5_story.html}}}} managing director,{{cite news|last1=Craig|first1=Tim|last2=DeBonis|first2=Mike|title=D.C. Council Gears Up For Another Election|work=The Washington Post|date=January 5, 2011|page=B1}}{{cite news|last=Craig|first=Tim|title=Barry's Grip May Weaken, But He's Not About To Let Go|work=The Washington Post|date=March 22, 2012|page=B1|postscript=none}}; {{cite news|last=McCartney|first=Robert|title=Barry Fails to Make Good With 'Good Asian'|work=The Washington Post|date=April 8, 2012|page=C1}}{{Efn|Jacque Patterson, chairperson of the Ward 8 Democrats, was managing director in 2011.}} a director of finance and administration, a director of membership and events, a senior research associate, and a research associate.{{cite web|title=Staff|website=Federal City Council|date=2016|accessdate=December 14, 2016|url=http://www.federalcitycouncil.org/staff}} In 2013, the position of managing director was retitled deputy executive director.{{cite web|last=Poe|first=Sheryll|title=Beyond the Capitol Dome: D.C. Embraces Its Entrepreneurial Economy|website=Huffington Post|date=November 6, 2013|accessdate=November 27, 2016|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/sheryll-poe/beyond-the-capitol-dome-d_b_4227752.html}}{{Efn|Emeka Moneme, a former transportation executive with the city and Metro, was hired as an page.title: Fellow of the American College of Surgeons

revision.comment: moved unrelated FASCRS to see also section
revision.text:
'''Fellow of the [[American College of Surgeons]]''', often listed as "FACS", is a [[Post-nominal letters|post-nominal title]] used to indicate that the surgeon's education and training, professional qualifications, surgical competence, and ethical conduct have passed a rigorous evaluation, and have been found to be consistent with the high standards established and demanded by said College. In order to apply for membership, a surgeon typically must be certified by a board member of the [[American Board of Medical Specialties]].
==See also== *[[Fellowship of the Royal Colleges of Surgeons]] (FRCS) *[[Fellow of the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons]] (FRACS) *Fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada|Royal College of Surgeons of Canada]] (FRCSC) *Fellow of the [[American Society of Colon and Rectal Surgeons]] (FASCRS) *Fellow of the [[Society of Critical Care Medicine|American College of Critical Care Medicine]] (FCCM)
==External links== *[http://www.facs.org/ American College of Surgeons]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fellow Of The American College Of Surgeons}} [[Category:Surgery]] [[Category:Professional titles and certifications]]
{{business-org-stub}}

revision.comment: clean up, removed: | ethnicity = [[Portuguese Brazilian]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://perfilimobiliario.com/site/?m=200906 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019100435
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Francisco Ivens de Sá Dias Branco | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1934|8|3}} | birth_place = [[Cedro]], Brazil | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|6|24|1934|8|3}} | death_place = | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = Brazilian | other_names = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Businessman]] | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = |net_worth = {{decrease}}[[US$]] 4.2 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] (January 2015) | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = Maria Consuelo Leon Scott Dias Branco | partner = | children = 5 | parents = Manuel Dias Branco
Maria Vidal de Sa Branco | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Francisco Ivens de Sá Dias Branco''' (August 3, 1934 – June 24, 2016) was a Brazilian businessman and one of the richest people in the world according to ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine, with an estimated net worth of $4.2 billion in January 2015.https://www.forbes.com/profile/francisco-dias-branco/ ==Personal life== He was born on August 3, 1934, in [[Cedro]], [[Ceará]], son of Manuel Dias Branco and Maria Vidal de Sa Branco, both of Portuguese ancestry.{{cite web |url=http://perfilimobiliario.com/site/?m=200906 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019100435/http://perfilimobiliario.com/site/?m=200906 |archivedate=2011-10-19 |df= }} Ivens was married to Maria Consuelo Leon Scott Dias Branco, their born children: Francisco Ivens, Francisco Marcos, Claudio Francisco, Maria Regina and Maria das Gracas. He is considered the first billionaire in the Northeast region of Brazil (the poorest).{{cite web |url=http://www.blogdatametrica.com.br/2012/03/o-nordeste-ja-tem-seu-bilionario.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720130734/http://www.blogdatametrica.com.br/2012/03/o-nordeste-ja-tem-seu-bilionario.html |archivedate=2012-07-20 |df= }} ==Career== As a business dynamic and entrepreneurial activities in the sector in which it operates, participated in two specialization courses for the industrial production of biscuits and pasta, made in Germany and England. Promotes travel abroad each year in order to attend Congresses and conferences related to his business. His Business also extend to the construction industry and hospitality. Ivens was chairman of the board of the group. His performance as a business man received great boost from the relocation of the factory to Fortaleza Br, where he set an enterprise with 62,000 meters square covered area and served as a landmark for the location of various projects on site. Diversified its activities with persistence and determination, and the group consisting of M. Dias Branco S / A - Com and Ind, M. Adm. And Dias Branco Investments Ltd., White Real Estate Ltd. Days; Idibra Incorporadora Ltda; Idibra Food Products From Maranhão and De Natal Services, Automotive Services Ltd.; Fabripan Industrial Ltda, Hotel Praia Centro S / A; Rural Enterprise Valley Gurguéia S / A ; New Town Real Estate Ltd.; Finopan Industrial Ltda, Fasal - St. Anthony Farm Company Ltd. And Ind. E De Vegetables Products Ltd., occupying positions of importance in the management of companies, which employ, as a whole, about 5,000 workers.http://www.fiec.org.br/documentacao/prem/comeind/pers_merito/fisdb.asp ==See also== * [[List of Brazilians by net worth]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Branco, Francisco Ivens de Sa Dias}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]] [[Category:Brazilian billionaires]] [[Category:Brazilian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Ceará]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:People from South Australia]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{notability|date=October 2017}}
'''Eric Fraser Ainsworth''' (known as '''Fraser Ainsworth''') is a South Australian businessperson active in the energy and resources sectors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/markets/stocks|title=Stocks|website=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.4-traders.com/business-leaders/Eric-Ainsworth-06D6NT-E/biography/|title=Eric Fraser Ainsworth - Biography|last=4-traders|website=www.4-traders.com|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref> He received a [[Centenary Medal]] in 2001 and became a Member of the [[Order of Australia]] in 2003. He retired from his position as chairman of Horizon Oil Ltd in 2015 and was inducted into the [[Australian Institute of Energy]]'s Hall of Fame the same year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aie.org.au/hall-of-fame|title=Hall of fame · South Australia · Australian Institute of Energy|website=www.aie.org.au|language=en|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aie.org.au/data/pdfs/hall_of_fame/Fraser_Ainsworth_AM_2015_AIE_SA_Hall_of_Fame_Citation_E3.pdf|title=Fraser Ainsworth AM - Induction into Australian Institute of Energy, South Australia Hall of Fame - Wednesday 5th August 2015|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rigzone.com/news/oil_gas/a/141181/horizon_oil_limited_chairman_to_retire|title=Horizon Oil Limited Chairman to Retire|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref>
In March 2017, Ainsworth signed an open letter calling for the Government of South Australia to continue to investigate the "opportunity to develop an international used nuclear fuel management industry" identified by the [[Nuclear Fuel Cycle Royal Commission]] in 2015-16.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brightnewworld.org/media/2017/3/3/an-open-letter-to-south-australias-elected-members-and-political-parties-2-march-2017|title=An open letter to South Australia’s elected members and political parties 2 March 2017|work=Bright New World|access-date=2018-02-15|language=en-AU}}</ref>
== Personal life == Fraser Ainsworth and his wife Kelly placed their [[Millswood, South Australia|Millswood]] home on the market in June 2017 with an anticipated sale price of $AUD 3.5-3.7 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/property/prestige-property-for-sale-across-australia/news-story/603e5aa636008ac2a7cd3426c4b49dda|title=Prestige property|last=Pettafor|first=Emily|date=2017-06-23|access-date=2017-09-30}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ainsworth, Fraser}} [[Category:living people]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:People from South Australia]]

/* References */
revision.text:
'''Göran Ehrnrooth ''' (1 April 1905 [[Helsinki]] – 9 January 1996 Helsinki) was a bank manager in Union Bank (Pohjoismaiden Yhdyspankki, later after several mergers [[Nordea]]. Göran Ehrnrooth worked for the Union Bank since 1933. He launched [[Mandatum]]. His successor was [[Mika Tiivola]].<ref name=Goran >[http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/kb/artikkeli/7130/ Ehrnrooth, Göran (1905–1996)] National Bibliography [[Finnish Literature Society]]</ref>
== Industry == The family business included the paper and board factory Kaukas and oil business Petko, that was later sold to [[British Petroleum]]. Investments e.g. in the paper factory [[Ahlström]] Oy, Hyvilla and [[Tampella]].<ref name=Goran/>
== Family == Göran Ehrnrooth was married to Louise von Julin, daughter of Elsa Lovisa Standertskjöld and Jacob von Julin (1906–1987), the CEO of Kaukas paper factory. Their children are [[Casimir Ehrnrooth]] (b. 1931) CEO [[UPM-Kymmene]], [[Göran J. Ehrnrooth]] (b. 1934) CEO [[Fiskars]], [[Robert Ehrnrooth]] (b. 1939) CEO EFFOA-Suomen Höyrylaiva ([[Silja Line]]) and Elsa Margaretha Louise Fromond (b. 1942).<ref name=Goran/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ehrnrooth, Goran}} [[Category:1905 births]] [[Category:1996 deaths]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Helsinki]] [[Category:People from Uusimaa Province (Grand Duchy of Finland)]] [[Category:Swedish-speaking Finns]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:Finnish bankers]]

{{Infobox Ambassador | honorific-prefix = | name = Hans Hertell | honorific-suffix = | image = | imagesize = | order = | ambassador_from = United States | country = the Dominican Republic | term_start = November 29, 2001 | term_end = May 1, 2007 | predecessor = | successor = | president = [[George W. Bush]] | birth_date = | birth_place = [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = United States | party = [[New Progressive Party of Puerto Rico|New Progressive Party]]
[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] | otherparty = | spouse = Marie | partner = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = [[Fordham University]]
[[University of Puerto Rico at Rio Piedras|University of Puerto Rico-Rio Piedras]] | occupation = | profession = [[Diplomatic corps]] }} '''Hans Helmut Hertell''' (born 1950/1951, [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]]) is a former United States [[Ambassador]] to the [[Dominican Republic]]. Nominated by President [[George W. Bush]] in the summer of 2001, Hertell was sworn in as [[Ambassador]] on November 8, 2001, and began his duties in the Dominican Republic on November 29, 2001. When he finished his tour on May 1, 2007, Ambassador Hertell was the second longest serving [[U.S. Ambassador]] in the world. ==Preamble== Hertell was a co-founder of '''Goldman, Antonetti, Ferraiuoli, Axtmayer and Hertell''', now the third largest full service law firm in Puerto Rico. From 1992-96, Hertell was managing director for the Caribbean and Latin America affairs at ''Black, Kelly, Scruggs & Healey'', a government and public affairs company based in [[Washington, D.C.]] In 1989, he served as a member of the Commission to Review U.S. Magistrates for Reappointment of the U.S. District Court for the District of Puerto Rico. Between 1982-84, he served as political and legal advisor to the [[Governor of Puerto Rico]], as well as to the [[Attorney General]], the Secretary of Agriculture and the Secretary of the Treasury of the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. ==Ambassador== Hertell was sworn in as the United States Ambassador to the Dominican Republic on November 8, 2001. At the time the Dominican Republic was the fourth largest trading partner of the United States in the Western Hemisphere after Canada, Brazil and Mexico and the largest economy in Central America and the Caribbean. In April 2007, Hertell officially left his post as ambassador.[http://www.dominicantoday.com/app/article.aspx?id=23455 U.S. ambassador Hans Hertell and his wife Marie bid farewell tonight], dominicantoday.com; accessed April 4, 2016. He was replaced by [[Chargé d'affaires]] Roland W. Bullen, who served as the interim head of the embassy until mid-November 2007.[http://www.usemb.gov.do/Ambassador/index-e.htm Embassy of the United States in the Dominican Republic] On November 15, 2007, P. Robert Fannin was sworn in as the new ambassador.[http://www.dominicantoday.com/app/article.aspx?id=25900 Robert Fannin is confirmed as new U.S. ambassador in Dominican Republic], Dominicantoday.com, October 29, 2007. ==Post-Ambassador years== Hertell remains active in fundraising for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]].[http://www.opensecrets.org/bush/ambassadors/hertell.asp THE BUSH ADMINISTRATION-Embassy Row: Hans Hertell], opensecrets.org; accessed April 4, 2016. He holds a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree from [[Fordham University]] of [[New York City]] and a [[juris doctor]] from the [[University of Puerto Rico]]. He is also involved with the operations and investments of the [[Barrick Gold]] Corporation in the Dominican Republic.[http://www.usprgold.com/company-info/management-team U.S. Precious Metals management team], usprgold.com; accessed April 4, 2016. He has been the Chairman of the Board at U.S. Precious Metals, Inc since January 9, 2015. He has been a Director of U.S. Precious Metals, Inc since May 31, 2013 and Colt Resources Inc. since April 14, 2015. He also serves as a Director of InterEnergy Holdings.[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=241158363&privcapId=9778687 Profile], bloomberg.com; accessed April 4, 2016. In 2009, Hertell [[lobbied]] with Dominican authorities for the required permissions and licenses.[http://www.dominicantoday.com/dr/economy/2009/2/10/31036/print Barrick Gold to invest more than US$3B in Dominican mine], dominicantoday.com, February 10, 2009; accessed April 4, 2016. ==References== {{DEFAULTSORT:Hertell, Hans}} [[Category:1950s births]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Puerto Rican people of German descent]] [[Category:Puerto Rican politicians]] [[Category:Puerto Rican lawyers]] [[Category:Puerto Rican businesspeople]] [[Category:People from San Juan, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Republican Party (Puerto Rico) politicians]]

{{coord|40|45|16|N|73|58|33|W|display=title|region:US-NY_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} {{Infobox building | name = Helmsley Building | image = Helmsley 47 partsun jeh.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | map_dot_label = | relief = | former_names = New York General Building
New York Central Building | alternate_names = | etymology = | status = Complete | cancelled = | topped_out = | building_type = Office | architectural_style = [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts]] | classification = | location = | address = 230 Park Avenue | location_city = [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]] [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | location_country = [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|45|16|N|73|58|33|W|format=dms}} | altitude = | current_tenants = | namesake = | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = 1927 | topped_out_date = | completion_date = 1929 | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | relocated_date = | renovation_date = 2004 | closing_date = | demolition_date = | cost = | ren_cost = | client = | owner = [[RXR Realty]] | landlord = | affiliation = | height = {{convert|565|ft|m}} | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | floor_count = 35 | floor_area = | elevator_count = 25 | grounds_area = | architect = | architecture_firm = [[Warren and Wetmore]] | developer = [[New York Central Railroad Company]] | engineer = | ren_awards = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | rooms = | parking = | url = {{URL|http://helmsleybuilding.com/}} | embed = | embedded = {{Designation list | embed = yes | designation1 = NYC | designation1_date = 31 March 1987 | designation1_number = [http://s-media.nyc.gov/agencies/lpc/lp/1297.pdf LP-1297] }} | references = {{cite web|url=https://www.emporis.com/buildings/114271/230-park-avenue-new-york-city-ny-usa|title=230 Park Avenue|website=[[Emporis]]|accessdate=2 May 2017}} | footnotes = }} '''The Helmsley Building''' is a 35-story building located at 230 [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Avenue]] between [[45th Street (Manhattan)|East 45th]] and [[46th Street (Manhattan)|East 46th]] Streets in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]], which was built in 1929 as the '''New York Central Building''', and was designed by [[Warren & Wetmore]], the architects of [[Grand Central Terminal]], in the [[Beaux-Arts architecture|Beaux-Arts style]]. Before the completion of the Pan Am Building—now the [[MetLife Building]]—this building stood out over the city's second most prestigious avenue as the tallest structure in the great "Terminal City" complex around Grand Central.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecityreview.com/helmsley.html|title=The Helmsley Building|accessdate=2006-05-17}}White, Norval & Willensky, Elliot; ''[[American Institute of Architects|AIA]] Guide to New York City'', 4th Edition; New York Chapter, [[American Institute of Architects]]; Crown Publishers/Random House. 2000. {{ISBN|0-8129-3106-8}}; {{ISBN|0-8129-3107-6}}. p.277. Traffic exits and enters the [[Park Avenue Viaduct]] through the building, through two portals, one for uptown traffic and one for downtown. They connect to Park Avenue proper at East 46th Street. The building was designated a New York City Landmark in 1987.Dolkart, Matthew A. MO & Postal, Matthew A.: ''Guide to New York City Landmarks; Third Edition'': The [[New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission]]; John Wiley & Sons, Inc; 2004. {{ISBN|0-471-36900-4}}. P.118. == History == === New York Central Building === Before the electrification of the [[New York Central Railroad]] in 1912–1913, the neighborhood north of Grand Central Terminal was one of open-air railway yards and tracks used by steam locomotives. The electrification and subsequent covering of the yards enabled the continuation of Park Avenue to the north and the construction of new buildings (with curious foundations). Among them was the New York Central Building. In 1913, '''New York Central''' unveiled a concept for a visual termination point in the city. Although the original plan was to have this termination point be over New York Central's [[Grand Central Terminal]], the concept was instead realized in the form of '''The New York Central Building''' just across the street to the north. The New York Central Railroad Company built their 34-story headquarters at 230 [[Park Avenue (Manhattan)|Park Ave.]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] in 1929. On September 10, 1931, [[capo di tutti capi]] [[Salvatore Maranzano]] was murdered in his ninth-floor office here by hitmen sent by [[Lucky Luciano]] and [[Vito Genovese]], ambitious underlings whom Maranzano had hired [[Vincent Coll|Vincent "Mad Dog" Coll]] to kill.{{cite web|url=http://www.nysonglines.com/4av.htm|title=4th Avenue: New York Songlines|accessdate=2006-05-17}} [[File:NY Central Building Tower Cropped.jpg|thumb|287px|Tower top, from the South side]] [[File:Helmsley Building detail.jpg|thumb|287px|Clock and sculptures over the entrance]] [[File:A Rolls Royce 1981 at 230 Park Avenue - in front The Helmsley Building.jpg|thumb|287px| 230 Park Avenue - The Helmsley Building]] [[File:Portal to Park Avenue.jpg|thumb|200px|Uptown traffic exits the [[Park Avenue Viaduct]] through the eastern portal of the Helmsley Building during "Summer Streets", when 7 miles of New York City streets are closed to vehicular traffic.]] ====Exterior==== The building is a slab-sided skyscraper between East 45th and East 46th Street, with a distinctive design that includes a means of transporting Park Avenue from street level to the divided aerial highway that passes through the building, and then around Grand Central Terminal to 42nd Street, and then back to street level. The top of the building is pyramidal, and capped by an ornate [[cupola]]. ====Interior==== "The impressive lobby, planned as a corridor connecting 45th and 46th Streets, echoes the magnificence of the exterior. The design and ornamentation celebrate the prowess of the New York Central Railroad, which had its headquarters on the premises. A sense of imperial grandeur is created by marble walls and bronze detail, which includes extensive use of the railroad’s initials. The Chinese Red elevator doors open into cabs with red walls, wood moldings, gift domes, and painted [[cloudscape (art)|cloudscapes]]". === New York General Building === When [[New York Central Railroad Company|New York Central]] sold the building, [[General Tire|General Tire & Rubber Company]] renamed the building the '''New York General Building'''. The building was easily renamed as the "C" and "T" in Central were chiseled into "G" and "E" respectively. === The Helmsley Building === When General Tire & Rubber Company sold the building to Helmsley-Spear, [[Leona Helmsley]] renamed the building '''The Helmsley Building''', which is its current name. The deal in which the ownership of this {{convert|2300000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} building, which was owned by the [[Helmsley-Spear|Helmsley-Spear Management]] until August 1998, changed hands stipulated that the building would not be renamed again. The building was purchased by Max Capital for $253 million, but in 2006 was sold again to [[Istithmar]], an investment firm owned by the royal family of Dubai, for $705 million. It was later sold to [[Goldman Sachs]] in 2007 for over $1 billion.[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=114271 Emporis: 230 Park Avenue] In May 2015, the building was sold for $1.2 billion to property firm [[RXR Realty]].{{cite web|author=Herbert Lash |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/05/us-usa-property-mondayproperties-helmsle-idUSKBN0NQ29M20150505 |title= New York's Helmsley Building sold for $1.2 billion to RXR Reality |publisher=Reuters |date=5 May 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2015}} ==Tenants== *[[Ronn Torossian|5W Public Relations (5WPR)]]{{cite web|url=https://commercialobserver.com/2016/12/wendy-williams-pr-firm-inks-43k-sf-deal-at-helmsley-building/|title=Wendy Williams’ PR Firm Inks 43K-SF Deal at Helmsley Building|last=Cullen|first=Terence|date=December 22, 2016|work=Commercial Observer|accessdate=April 30, 2018}} *[[Cornell University]][http://www.commercialobserver.com/2011/04/toptier-safety-school-takes-10kplus-feet/ Top-Tier Safety School Takes 10K-Plus Feet] *[[Comerica Bank]] *Desmarais LLP[https://commercialobserver.com/2018/05/desmarais-lease-helmsley-building-230-park-avenue-rxr-realty/ Intellectual Property Law Firm Desmarais Expands at Helmsley Building] *[[Elsevier]]{{cite web |first=Hiten |last=Samtani |title=Publisher Reed Elsevier to take 71,000 square feet at Invesco’s Helmsley Building |url=http://therealdeal.com/2013/07/29/publisher-reed-elsevier-to-become-largest-tenant-at-invescos-helmsley-building |work=The Real Deal |date=July 29, 2013 |accessdate=April 30, 2018}} *[[Encyclopædia Britannica]][http://www.commercialobserver.com/2009/11/mondays-230-park-racks-up-marquee-tenants-encyclopdia-britannica-stanley-tools-new-york-city/ Monday’s 230 Park Racks Up Marquee Tenants: Encyclopædia Britannica, Stanley Tools, New York City] *Guest Services Worldwide *[[HSH Nordbank AG]][http://www.hsh-nordbank.com/en/regionen/nordamerika_4/newyork_1/newyork_1.jsp/ HSH Nordbank AG New York Office] *Hunt Mortgage Group *[[New York Court of Appeals]] *[[Novartis]][http://www.commercialobserver.com/2011/01/monday-fills-last-full-towerfloor-space-at-230-park/ Monday Fills Last Full Tower-Floor Space at 230 Park] *[[Powermat]] *[[Simon Property Group]][http://observer.com/2010/10/countrys-biggest-landlord-picks-230-park-for-nyc-hq/ Country’s Biggest Landlord Picks 230 Park for NYC HQ] *[[Six Flags]][http://www.commercialobserver.com/2010/01/six-flags-rollercoaster-views-10year-lease-in-mondays-230-park/ Six Flags’ Roller-Coaster Views: 10-Year Lease in Monday’s 230 Park] *[[Stanley Hand Tools]] *[[Tokio Marine Nichido|Tokio Marine Management]] *Upper Bay Infrastructure Partners *[[Voya Financial]][http://www.crainsnewyork.com/dcce/20080422/12/real_estate/122/deals_active/2383176 Four tenants sign at Helmsley Building] *Zinkovetsky Law Firm ==In popular culture== *One of the promotional posters for the 2008 film ''[[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]]'' shows the building with an explosion the shape of the [[Batman emblem]] on its upper floors. *The building is shown as one of the skyscrapers still standing in the movie ''[[A.I. Artificial Intelligence]]''. *It was also used as one of the New York City filming locations for the non-narrative film ''[[Baraka (film)|Baraka]]''. *An interior boardroom was used in ''[[The Godfather]]'', as the location of an important meeting between New York's [[Five Families]], to show their influence in society. Railroad murals can be seen behind the actors. However, the exterior used for the shot was the [[Federal Reserve Bank of New York Building]] at [[33 Liberty Street]]. *In [[Ayn Rand]]'s ''[[Atlas Shrugged]]'', the Helmsley Building is described as the Taggart Transcontinental Railroad Building, the office of the protagonist of the novel, Dagny Taggart. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Helmsley Building}} *[http://www.in-arch.net/NYC/nyc2.html#20 in-Arch.net: The Helmsley Building] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Warren and Wetmore buildings]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Park Avenue]] [[Category:Beaux-Arts architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Commercial buildings completed in 1929]] [[Category:Grand Central Terminal]]

revision.comment: [[User:Addbot|Bot:]] Migrating 1 interwiki links, now provided by [[Wikipedia:Wikidata|Wikidata]] on [[d:q1654188]]
revision.text:
{{for|the networking device|Intelligent Network Interface Device}} '''INID''' is an [[acronym]] for '''Internationally agreed Numbers for the Identification of (bibliographic) Data'''.<ref name="st9">{{cite web|url=http://www.wipo.int/standards/en/pdf/03-09-01.pdf|title=WIPO standard ST.9}}</ref> INID codes are used by [[patent office]]s worldwide for indicating specific bibliographic data items on the title pages of [[patent]]s and patent application publications. INID codes use Arabic numerals, and so are language-independent. For example, number ''(30)'' indicates priority data, and ''(51)'' technical area according to the [[International Patent Classification]] (IPC).<ref>Example for INID codes on the [http://v3.espacenet.com/origdoc?DB=EPODOC&F=0&IDX=EP0123456&QPN=EP0123456 front page] of {{Patent|EP|0123456}}</ref>
INID codes are standardised by [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) in ST.9.<ref name="st9" /> [[File:Sample patent to illustrate "INID" numbers.png|thumb|Sample patent to illustrate "INID" numbers. The INID numbers are those within brackets, such as "(10)" before the patent number.]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.wipo.int/standards/en/pdf/03-09-01.pdf ST.9 Standards section of the WIPO Handbook on Industrial Property and Information, which contains the INID codes]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Inid}} [[Category:Intellectual property law]] [[Category:Patent law]]

revision.comment: sp.: [[International Labour Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Independent Contractors Australia |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |abbreviation = ICA |formation = 2000 |type = Not-For-Profit |status = Association |purpose = Representation of independent contractors in the Australian workplace |headquarters = [[Melbourne, Victoria]] |location = [[Australia]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = http://www.independentcontractors.net.au }} '''Independent Contractors of Australia (ICA)''' was established in 1999, with the aim to create a national association to represent [[independent contractors]] in the Australian workplace.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/unleashed/ken-phillips-28588.html Australian Broadcasting Commission ''The Drum'']</ref><ref>[http://2011.businesscongress.com.au/speaker/ken-phillips/ Australian Chambers Business Congress 1-3 June 2011]</ref><ref>[http://www.fairwork.gov.au/resources/fact-sheets/workplace-rights/Pages/independent-contractors-and-emplyees-fact-sheet.aspx ''Fairwork Australia'' Fact Sheet]</ref> [[Independent contractors]] operate in the workplace by contracting out their services rather than being engaged under an employment agreement. They are able to be distinguished from employees by some key differences. [[Independent contractors]] operate their business entity in order to provide a good or service for an agreed price usually stipulated in a commercial contract. Other differences are that in most cases [[independent contractors]] are paid for the results they achieve; provide the materials and equipment needed to complete the work they do and are free to delegate their work to others. Also, they are free to accept or refuse work and may make a profit or a loss from the contracts they enter into with their clients.<ref>[http://www.business.gov.au/BusinessTopics/Independentcontractors/Documents/Independentcontractorstheessentialhandbook.pdf ''Independent Contractors The Essential Handbook'' Commonwealth of Australia (Department of Industry, Innovation, Science, Research and Tertiary Education)2011 pp 2-3]</ref> ICA is a not-for-profit association incorporated under the Associations Incorporation Act (1981) of Victoria.<ref>[http://www.business.gov.au/GBDirectory/I/Pages/IndependentContractorsofAustralia.aspx ''Directory of Government and Business Associations'' in Australia]</ref>
==Governance==
ICA is governed by a [[Board of directors|Board]] under the rules established by its [[Articles of Association]].<ref name =brochure>[http://www.independentcontractors.net.au/Downloads/about/ICA-Brochure-June-2014.pdf ICA brochure]</ref>
=== Articles of Association ===
The articles<ref name =brochure/> under which ICA was established determine that the purpose of the association is: # to uphold and defend the right of all eligible Australians to engage in the [[labour market]] as free and [[independent contractors]], and to be recognised by [[governments]], tax officials and regulators as [[independent contractors]]; # to engage in lobbying and public debate to ensure that the Australian community is aware that if Australians' rights to engage freely in the labour market are impaired or denied, then the rights of all Australians to live in freedom will be at risk; # to maintain the common law distinctions which the courts have made between employment and contract in [[labour market]] relationships; # to take all such action as the association or the committee shall think conducive to the attainment of these objectives.
=== Board ===
The ICA constitution requires the election of ten Board members, with four who are [[independent contractors]], up to at least three who are company members, and up to three who are association members. The elected Board can then appoint an additional two members.
=== Past presidents ===
* The Hon [[Norman Lacy]] (November 2008 – Present) * Marie-Louise MacDonald (December 2007-November 2008) * Michael Kelson (April 2007-December 2007) * Angela MacRae (July 2005-April 2007) * [[Bob Day]] (2001-July 2005)
=== Executive Director ===
Ken Phillips has been Executive Director of ICA since 2000.<ref>[http://www.businessspectator.com.au/bs.nsf/Article/contractors-small-business-law-pd20091012-WR3MK?OpenDocument&src=is&cat=hr%20_%20education-al Business Spectator]</ref><ref>[http://www.thenationalsmallbusinesssummit.com.au/presenters/ken-phillips The NAB National Small Business Summit]</ref><ref>[http://www.onlineopinion.com.au/author.asp?id=111 Online Opinion]</ref>
==Funding, membership, and location==
ICA is funded by its membership fees and revenue raised from sponsorship, advertising and events. Membership is open to [[independent contractors]]; to companies who engage [[independent contractors]]; and to industry associations whose members engage independent contractors. Membership fees range from $50 per annum for individual affiliate members to $12,000 per annum for industry associations with more than 201 member companies.<ref name =brochure/>
There are 1.1 million [[independent contractors]] in the Australian workforce of 11.3 million. However, Other Business Operators (OBOs) are also self-employed and make up another 1 million workers.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) separates OBOs from independent contractors on the basis that they are self-employed workers whose primary activity is managing others (i.e. they have employees) and/or selling goods and services to earn income rather than relying on the provision of their labour. Whereas independent contractors are defined as workers who provide their time and labour and who only manage themselves. Hence the self-employed total 2.1 million and make up 18.6% of the total workforce.<ref>CFMEU, ''Race to the Bottom - Sham Contracting in Australia's Construction Industry. A report by CFMEU Construction & General'', March 2011, p 11</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! FORM OF EMPLOYMENT!! 2008!! 2009!! 2010!! 2008/2010 |- ! !! <small>(000)</small> !! <small>(000)</small> !! <small>(000)</small> !! <small>(%)</small> |- ! Total Workforce !! 10,651.1 !! 10,664.9 !! 11,300.0 !! 5.74 |- ! <small>Employees</small> !! <small>8,619.6</small> !! <small>8,660.9</small> !!
<small>9,2000.0</small> !! <small>6.31</small> |- ! <small>Independent Contractors</small> !! <small>967.1</small> !! <small>1,029.0</small> !!
<small>1,100.0</small> !! <small>12.08</small> |- ! <small>Other Business Operators</small> !! <small>1,064.4</small> !! <small>975.0</small> !!
<small>1,000.0</small> !! <small>-6.44</small> |- ! Total Self Employed !! 2,0331.5 !! 2,004.0 !! 2,100.0 !! 3.26 |- ! Self Employed/Workforce <small>(%)</small> !! 19.07 !! 18.79 !! 18.58 |} <ref>Australian Bureau of Statistics, ''Form of Employment Survey'', Cat. 6359.0, published data, November 2008, (updated with 2010 figures).</ref><ref>[http://www.ausstats.abs.gov.au/ausstats/subscriber.nsf/0/8C62E3501983EC5BCA2575D2001B01AE/$File/63590_nov%202008.pdf][http://www.independentcontractors.net.au/Research/How-Many/independent-contractors-how-many ''Independent Contractors: How Many?'']</ref>
ICA is based in [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. Board meetings are held monthly at 150 Lonsdale Street, [[Melbourne]],
==Mission== ICA's mission is to: * present to Government and the public a clear and positive view of [[independent contractors]]; * provide an ideal legal and professional framework in which [[independent contractors]] can thrive and feel legally secure; * support members by creating an environment that allows them to grow within the economy; * provide members with access to relevant services, including education, literature and news updates.
==Campaigns==
ICA's lobbying campaigns have focused on:
'''2000-2001''' the introduction of the Personal Services Income (Tax) legislation;<ref>[http://law.ato.gov.au/atolaw/view.htm?docid=TXR/TR20017/nat/ato/00001 ''Income tax: the meaning of personal services income'']</ref><ref>Australian Financial Review, ''Plea for Leniency on Contractors'', "The Howard Government may be forced to accept a lower revenue yield from its planned crackdown on contractors, prompting industry to lobby senior ministers for a more sympathetic contractor test." 24 March 2000</ref><ref>[http://www.afr.com/p/technology/ato_claims_crackdown_taxes_it_contractors_ia2fkKlTU4jGKrSffizN6O Australian Financial Review, ''ATO unreasonably rejects travel claims of IT contractors'', 7 August 2012]</ref>
'''2003–6''' participation in the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) debates regarding the ''Scope of the Employment Relationship'' resulting in a 2006 ILO Recommendation protecting the legitimacy of [[independent contractors]] and the commercial contract.
'''2005–6''' the introduction of the Independent Contractors' Act (2006).<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2006/s1669513.htm ABC transcript from ''The World Today'', ''Government Introduces Independent Contractors Bill to Parliament'', 22 June 2006]</ref><ref name="comlaw">[http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2012C00183 Independent Contractors Act 2006]</ref><ref>O'Malley Nick, Workplace Reporter, ''New Law Threatens Pay Rights of Workers'', Sydney Morning Herald, June 23, 2006</ref>
'''2007-2011''' the establishment of Small Business Commissioners in each state and territory and in the [[Commonwealth Government]].
'''2009-12''' the development and promotion of ''Charter of Contractual Fairness''<ref>[http://www.independentcontractors.net.au/Downloads/Members/ICA-Charter-of-Contractual-Fairness.pdf Charter of Contractual Fairness]</ref> to governments and corporations and to have the Trade Practices Act amended to extend the protections for contractual fairness, available to consumers, to small businesses.
==References==
{{Reflist}}
