revision.comment: /* Typical IBC Uses */
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}}
An '''international business company''' or '''international business corporation''' ('''IBC''') is an [[offshore company]] formed under the laws of some [[jurisdiction]]s as a tax neutral company which is usually limited in terms of the activities it may conduct in, but not necessarily from, the jurisdiction in which it is incorporated. While not taxable in the country of incorporation, an IBC or its owners, if resident in a country having "controlled foreign corporation" rules for instance can be taxable in other jurisdictions.
==Features== Characteristics of an IBC vary by jurisdiction, but will usually include: [[File:Chart of an offshore company structure.jpg|thumb|Chart of an offshore company structure]] * exemption from local corporate taxation and stamp duty, provided that the company engages in no local business (annual agent's fees and company registration taxes are still payable, which are normally a few hundred U.S. dollars per year) * preservation of confidentiality of the beneficial owner of the company * wide corporate powers to engage in different businesses and activities * abrogation or restriction of the requirement to demonstrate [[corporate benefit]] * the ability to issue [[stock|shares]] in either [[Registered instrument|registered]] or [[Bearer instrument|bearer]] form (although many countries have restricted or eliminated bearer shares now) * an abrogation of any requirements to appoint local directors or officers * provision for a local [[registered agent]] or registered office
It must be noted that all of the above characteristics are also attributable to many "onshore" countries which have either a residency or territorial based tax system where setting up a company, LLC or LLP in the jurisdiction along with the use of "nominees" will offer all of the above characteristics. US LLCs, UK LLPs and Hong Kong companies are all examples which are widely used in similar capacity to IBCs and which meet all of the characteristics above.
However, under pressure from the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) and the [[Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering]] (FATF), most offshore jurisdictions have removed or are removing the "ring fencing" of IBCs from local taxation. In most of the jurisdictions, this has been accompanied by reductions of levels of corporate tax to zero to avoid damaging the offshore finance industry.
In contrast, Seychelles residents are legally able to own and operate a Seychelles IBC as long as the IBC is not conducting business within Seychelles. Seychelles also has a "territorial" tax system meaning that Seychelles residents are only taxed on their locally sourced income. Therefore, there is no advantage to non-residents over residents and claims of "ring fencing" have no merit on the Seychelles IBC. This has been, and continues to be, used successfully by Seychelles in defense of the Seychelles IBC vs. international bodies such as the OECD and FATF. Boosting the defense even more is that there are no restrictions on a Seychelles IBC owning shares of a Seychelles domestic company.
Further, most jurisdictions have either eliminated or highly restricted the issuing of bearer shares by IBCs due to international pressures.
==The IBC legal entry== An IBC is a legal entity incorporated under specific legislation which is free from all local taxes (except small fixed annual fees). Typically the IBC is limited in the activities it may conduct in, but not necessarily from, the country of incorporation. [[Anguilla]], [[Bahamas]], [[Belize]], [[Dominica]], [[Nevis]], [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|St Vincent]] and [[Seychelles]] have special IBC legislation in place. The [[British Virgin Islands]] and [[Gibraltar]] formerly had popular IBC regimes, but in each case the relevant legislation has been repealed.<ref>For BVI, see [[BVI Business Companies Act]]</ref>
==Typical IBC Uses==
IBCs are offshore companies that are most commonly used for [[offshore bank]]ing to conduct international trade, investment activities, as a [[special purpose entity]], by professionals and for asset protection. Offshore companies can be involved in buying and selling goods and services, hold bank accounts and operate businesses. IBCs are also commonly used for the ownership of real property and land; for ownership of intellectual property, licensing and franchising; personal service by individuals working overseas and offshore e-business among other things.
The term [[Offshore company]] seems more commonly used than International Business Company (IBC). Although all IBCs are necessarily offshore companies, not all offshore companies are IBCs. Both terms refer broadly to a similar type of corporate structure. The term 'offshore' is used to refer to a company, or bank account, set up outside the jurisdiction of residence or place of doing business.
==See also== {{Portal|Economics}} * [[International Business Companies Act]] * [[List of company registers]] * [[Multinational corporation]] * [[Offshore bank]]
==Footnotes== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://micro.harneys.com/ibcact/ Video: The Story of the IBC Act]
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Business Company}} [[Category:International finance]] [[Category:Legal entities]] [[Category:Offshore finance]] [[Category:Types of business entity]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Jesus Vizcarra Calderon | image = Jesus Vizcarra Calderon Large.jpg | office = Mayor of Culiacan, Mexico | escudo = Culiacan Escudo.PNG | flag = {{flagicon|MEX}} [[Culiacán, Sinaloa]], México | profession = Businessman and politician | partido = [[Institutional Revolutionary Party]] |website = [http://www.vizcarrajesus.com Official Site of Jesus Vizcarra] }} '''Jesus Vizcarra Calderon''' ([[Culiacán, Sinaloa]], March 17, 1960) is a [[Mexico|Mexican]] businessman and politician.
== Biography ==
Vizcarra went to University in the city of Culiacan. Between 20 and 42 years old, he led various business organizations, getting to chair the National Agricultural Council and served on the Executive Committee of the Business Council for 4 years. Between 1998 and 2002 he chaired the Mexican Association of Feedlot Cattle. In 1971, he began working with [[Sukarne]], Formerly known as Viz Group, a company founded by his parents in 1969.
In 2003, his family established ''Salud Digna'', a nonprofit institution that has installed 33 centers for prevention and early diagnosis in Querétaro, Durango, Sinaloa, Nayarit, Coahuila, Jalisco, Sonora, Baja California, Guanajuato, Puebla, Aguascalientes, Mexico City<ref>[http://www.ganarsalud.com/news2/news.php?newsid=874 Salud Digna Caso de Estudio Universidad de Harvard] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110409010715/http://www.ganarsalud.com/news2/news.php?newsid=874 |date=April 9, 2011 }}</ref> and Los Angeles, California, the latter being the first Mexican clinic to provide these services to the Latino community. Today it is the most important institution of social health in Mexico, and in 2014 it will serve more than 3 million people.<ref>[http://www.sexenio.com.mx/queretaro/articulo.php?id=8748 Salud Digna la institución de salud social más importante de México]</ref> <ref>[http://www.grupoviz.mx/presidente-de-grupo-viz-y-fundador-de-salud-digna-inaugura-clinica-en-los-angeles/ Salud Digna inaugura clínica en Los Ángeles]</ref>
== Business Biography ==
Very young, Jesus joined the family business, Corrales Vizcarra, as auxiliary cattle marketing and channel. In 1980 he was responsible for the general management and, from 1985 took the Chair and Department of the company, under his command that has evolved into Sukarne. In October 2011, "Latin Business Association", featured Vizcarra as one of the most active Latino entrepreneurs in the United States, and was recognized for his career in leading SuKarne, in 2014 SuKarne was awarded the National Export Award <ref>[http://www.bancomext.com/notas-de-interes/5387 SuKarne Recibe el Premio Nacional de Exportación 2014]</ref> and Agrifood National Award by the president of Mexico.<ref>[http://sukarne.com/entrada/recibe-sukarne-premio-nacional-agroalimentario SuKarne Recibe el Premio Nacional Agroalimentario 2014]</ref> SuKarne recibe the and its strong push to bring health services to the poor people through Salud Digna.<ref>[http://mexicoenterado.com.mx/jesus-vizcarra-presidente-de-sukarne-es-reconocido-por-la-%e2%80%9clatin-business-asociation%e2%80%9d-por-su-trayectoria-empresarial Jesús Vizcarra es reconocido por la Latin Business Association]</ref>
He ranked 67th among the 100 most important businessmen in Mexico by the business magazine Expansion in 2013,<ref>[http://www.cnnexpansion.com/especiales/2013/10/23/empresarios-del-51-al-100 Jesús Vizcarra 100 empresarios mas importantes de México]</ref> and in 2012 was recognized by the Latino community in the United States (Estados Unidos de Norteamérica) for his project, Salud Digna.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FnZ_AqNEw3M Jesús Vizcarra reconocido por el proyecto Salud Digna]</ref>
SuKarne the principal company routinely exports to countries located on four continents. In 2014 started exports to Canada, Chile and China.<ref>[http://sukarne.com/en/page/sukarne-exports Crecen exportaciones de SuKarne]</ref>
== Political career ==
In 1988 Vizcarra joined the Institutional Revolutionary Party and served as a state and national political adviser in [[Guasave, Sinaloa]]. In 2003, he was sworn in as senator in the Fifth Federal District of Sinaloa; the same year he was named chairman of the Water Resources Commission and was a member of the Finance, Energy and Budget committees.
Vizcarra helped in the 2004 campaign to elect Jesus Aguilar Padilla governor of Sinaloa. In 2005, he served as Secretary of Economic Development of the Government of the State of Sinaloa. Subsequently, he ceded his position to campaign for mayor of Culiacán in 2007, where he earned the win. On January 1, 2008 was sworn into office.<ref>[http://www.periodicoregion.com/index.php?Itemid=37&id=844&option=com_content&task=view Protesta Jesús Vizcarra como presidente municipal de Culiacán]</ref>
In 2010, Vizcarra ran for governor of Sinaloa under the ''Alianza Para Ayudar a la Gente'', supported by the [[Partido Revolucionario Institucional|PRI]], [[Ecologist Green Party of Mexico|PVEM]] and [[New Alliance Party (Mexico)|PANAL]]. Although some polls gave him a 6-point lead over his opponent, Mario López Valdez, he lost the election, losing with 46.4 percent to López Valdez's 51.8 percent.
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://sukarne.com/ Official Corporate Site of SuKarne] * [http://www.grupoviz.mx Official Site of Grupo Viz] * [http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/columnas/91090.html Jesus Vizcarra Propels Sukarne] * [http://www.ganandoeninternet.com/jesus-vizcarra-calderon-grupo-viz-sukarne-empresario-con-vision Jesus Vizcarra Calderon. A man with a vision.]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Vizcarra, Jesus}} [[Category:Mexican businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)]] [[Category:Mayors of places in Mexico]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:People from Sinaloa]] [[Category:Institutional Revolutionary Party politicians]]

revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=January 2012}} '''Joaquín Ayuso García''' (born 1955 in [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]). [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[Grupo Ferrovial]], one of the world's leading infrastructure groups in terms of earnings and market capitalisation with more than 100,000 employees.
==Career== He joined Ferrovial in 1982, starting as site engineer; he was subsequently promoted to Project Supervisor, Group Manager, Area Manager and Regional Manager. From 1999 to 2002, he was [[CEO]] of ''"Ferrovial Agromán"'', the Group's construction arm.
==Education== Ayuso graduated in [[Civil Engineering]] from the [[Universidad Politécnica de Madrid]].
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{es icon}} *[http://www.ferrovial.com/ Grupo Ferrovial Website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ayuso, Joaquin}} [[Category:Spanish businesspeople]] [[Category:Polytechnic University of Madrid alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1955 births]]
{{Spain-business-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Justin Rockefeller | image = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = Justin Aldrich Rockefeller | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|07|12}} | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Impact Investor & Financial Technologist | alma_mater = [[Princeton University]] {{small|[[Bachelor of Arts|(B.A.)]]}} | networth = | spouse = {{marriage|Indré Vengris Rockefeller|2006}} | children = | parents = [[Jay Rockefeller]]
[[Sharon Percy Rockefeller]] | residence = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. }} '''Justin Aldrich Rockefeller''' (born July 12, 1979){{cite web|url=http://www.worth.com/Editorial/Thought-Leaders/Profiles/Visions-Revisions-Democratic-Zeal-3.asp |title=Visions and Revisions Page 3 Worth |date=2006-09-01 |accessdate=2008-08-08 |publisher=Worth |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122005320/http://www.worth.com/Editorial/Thought-Leaders/Profiles/Visions-Revisions-Democratic-Zeal-3.asp |archivedate=2008-11-22 |df= }}) is an American impact investor and financial technology professional. Rockefeller was born on July 12, 1979, in [[West Virginia]], the youngest son of former West Virginia senator, [[Jay Rockefeller]] (b. 1937), and his wife, [[Sharon Percy Rockefeller]] (b. 1944). Rockefeller's maternal grandfather was former U.S. Senator [[Charles H. Percy]] (1919–2011), and his paternal grandparents were [[Blanchette Ferry Rockefeller|Blanchette Ferry Hooker]] (1909–1992) and [[John D. Rockefeller III]] (1906–1978), the eldest son of philanthropists [[John D. Rockefeller Jr.]] and [[Abby Aldrich Rockefeller]].{{cite news|last1=Hallemann|first1=Caroline|title=What It's Like to be a Rockefeller in 2016|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/tradition/news/a6149/justin-rockefeller-interview/|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=[[Town and Country Magazine|Town & Country]]|date=11 May 2016|language=en}} ==Career== Rockefeller is the Global Director of Family Offices and Foundations at [https://addepar.com/ Addepar],{{cite web|title=Global Conference 2016 Speaker: Justin Rockefeller|url=http://www.milkeninstitute.org/events/conferences/global-conference/2016/speaker-detail/23412|website=milkeninstitute.org|publisher=[[Milken Institute]]|accessdate=21 March 2017}} a financial technology company. Rockefeller cofounded and chairs the board of directors of [http://theimpact.org The ImPact] a membership network of family enterprises (family offices, foundations, and businesses) that are committed to making investments with measurable social impact. The ImPact provides families with the knowledge and network they need to make more impact investments more effectively, and uses sophisticated technology, [[Addepar]], for data aggregation, analysis, and reporting to shift the narrative of impact investing from one of inputs (dollars committed) to outcomes (impact created). The purpose of The ImPact is to improve the probability and pace of solving social problems by increasing the ow of capital to investments generating measurable social impact.{{Cite news|url=http://im.ft-static.com/content/images/e1b08e5c-9686-11e6-a80e-bcd69f323a8b.pdf|title=FT Wealth Investors With Impact|last=Foley|first=Stephen|date=December 1, 2016|work=The Financial Times|accessdate=December 6, 2017|archive-url=|archivedate=|dead-url=}} From 2009 - 2018, Rockefeller served on the board and the investment committee of [https://www.rbf.org/ Rockefeller Brothers Fund]; in those capacities, he helped the private foundation align its endowment with its mission.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1003317577|title=Generation impact : how next gen donors are revolutionizing giving|last=1974-|first=Goldseker, Sharna |others=Moody, Michael Patrick, 1967-|isbn=9781119422815|location=Hoboken|oclc=1003317577}} He also serves on the board of Japan Society, and speaks occasionally about impact investing, family offices, and technology, including at the [https://www.weforum.org/ World Economic Forum at Davos], [http://www.milkeninstitute.org/ Milken Institute], [https://www.ypo.org/ Young Presidents' Organization|YPO], etc. Previously, Justin was Venture Partner at Richmond Global, LLC, a global venture capital firm focusing on technology-enabled services and mobile technologies in the U.S. and across major emerging markets. Justin’s previous board memberships include: Voxiva, Inc.; Rockefeller Family Fund; [http://www.popcouncil.org/ Population Council]; The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art; the Alliance for the Arts; and [[Generation Engage]], which he cofounded in 2004. He also served on the National Leadership Council for [https://www.glsen.org/ GLSEN] – the Gay, Lesbian, Straight Education Network, and on the NY State Commission on National and Community Service. ==Personal life== In 2006, Rockefeller, who lives in [[New York City]], married{{cite news|title=SEN. ROCKEFELLER, WIFE ANNOUNCE MARRIAGE OF JUSTIN ROCKEFELLER TO INDRÉ VENGRIS|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-1132636341.html|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=US Fed News Service, Including US State News|date=15 September 2006}} Indré Vengris, a dancer{{cite news|last1=Sulcas|first1=Roslyn|title=The Chamber Dance Project - Dance - Review|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/08/arts/dance/08cham.html|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 December 2007}}{{cite news|last1=Macaulay|first1=Alastair|title=Couples: Balanchine on the Man-Woman Thing, at Kennedy Center|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/14/arts/dance/14suza.html|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 October 2008}} and fashion executive.{{cite news|last1=Bray|first1=Sarah|title=Inside The Home Of Moda Operandi's Indre Rockefeller|url=http://www.elledecor.com/celebrity-style/celebrity-homes/news/g772/indre-rockefeller-home-nyc/|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=ELLE Decor|date=10 February 2014|language=en}}{{cite news|last1=Halberg|first1=Morgan|title=Justin and Indre Rockefeller Part Ways With Eclectic Park Avenue Home|url=http://observer.com/2016/08/justin-and-indre-rockefeller-part-ways-with-eclectic-park-avenue-home/|accessdate=21 March 2017|work=[[The Observer]]|date=12 August 2016}} ==See also== *[[Rockefeller family]] *[[Jay Rockefeller]] *[[Sharon Percy Rockefeller]] *[[Charles H. Percy]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rockefeller, Justin}} [[Category:Rockefeller family]] [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:People from Pocahontas County, West Virginia]] [[Category:Businesspeople from New York City]] [[Category:Dudley–Winthrop family]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:American venture capitalists]] {{US-activist-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Early years */He is half African American due to his dad being full African American. Previously incorrect information on page stating he was a “quarter” African American.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Chris Humphreys|Chris Humphrey}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{infobox NBA biography | name = Kris Humphries | image = Kris Humphries (33696753930).jpg | caption = Humphries with the Hawks in 2017 | position = [[Power forward (basketball)|Power forward]] / [[Center (basketball)|Center]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 9 | weight_lb = 238 | league = | team = Free agent | number = | nationality = American | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|2|6}} | birth_place = [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | high_school = [[Hopkins High School|Hopkins]] ([[Minnetonka, Minnesota]]) | college = [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball|Minnesota]] (2003–2004) | draft_year = 2004 | draft_round = 1 | draft_pick = 14 | draft_team = [[Utah Jazz]] | career_start = 2004 | career_end = | years1 = {{nbay|2004|start}}–{{nbay|2005|end}} | team1 = [[Utah Jazz]] | years2 = {{nbay|2006|start}}–{{nbay|2008|end}} | team2 = [[Toronto Raptors]] | years3 = {{nbay|2009|full=y}} | team3 = [[Dallas Mavericks]] | years4 = {{nbay|2009|end}}–{{nbay|2012|end}} | team4 = [[Brooklyn Nets|New Jersey / Brooklyn Nets]] | years5 = {{nbay|2013|full=y}} | team5 = [[Boston Celtics]] | years6 = {{nbay|2014|start}}–{{nbay|2015|end}} | team6 = [[Washington Wizards]] | years7 = {{nbay|2015|end}} | team7 = [[Phoenix Suns]] | years8 = {{nbay|2015|end}}–{{nbay|2016|end}} | team8 = [[Atlanta Hawks]] | highlights = * First-team [[Parade All-America Boys Basketball Team|''Parade'' All-American]] (2003) | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport|Men's basketball}} {{MedalCountry|the {{USA}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIBA Americas Under-18 Championship|FIBA Americas U18 Championship]]}} {{MedalBronze| [[FIBA Americas Under-18 Championship|2002 Isla Margarita]] | [[United States national basketball team|National team]]}} }} '''Kristopher Nathan Humphries'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/hawks/features/kris-humphries-beat-michael-phelps-and-ryan-lochte-swimming-kid-and-heres-proof/|title=Kris Humphries Beat Michael Phelps and Ryan Lochte At Swimming As A Kid, And Here's Proof|work=NBA.com|date=August 15, 2016|accessdate=August 17, 2016}}</ref> (born February 6, 1985) is an American professional [[basketball]] player who last played for the [[Atlanta Hawks]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). He has also played in the NBA for the [[Utah Jazz]], [[Toronto Raptors]], [[Dallas Mavericks]], [[Brooklyn Nets|New Jersey / Brooklyn Nets]], [[Boston Celtics]], [[Washington Wizards]], and [[Phoenix Suns]]. Humphries played college basketball for the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers men's basketball|Minnesota Golden Gophers]] of the [[University of Minnesota]], and for the [[United States men's national basketball team]].
==Early years== Humphries was born in Minnesota to Debra and William Humphries. His father was a [[American football|football]] player, at the [[University of Minnesota]].<ref name=usa>{{cite web|title=USA Basketball Bio: Kris Humphries |url=http://www.usabasketball.com/biosmen/kris_humphries_bio.html |work=USABasketball.com |accessdate=April 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060327043119/http://www.usabasketball.com/biosmen/kris_humphries_bio.html |archivedate=March 27, 2006 }}</ref> Humphries is half African-American from his father.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kim Kardashian & Kris Humphries To Wed This Summer! Wedding Could Net Over $5 Million|url=http://www.realitytea.com/tag/kris-humphries-race/|work=RealityTea.com|date=May 27, 2011|accessdate=May 27, 2011}}</ref> He has two older sisters, Krystal and Kaela. His first success in sports came in competitive swimming, where he was the top 10-year-old in the nation in six events, first, beating young [[Michael Phelps]] in the remaining events. Kris Humphries held the US national record for the 50-meter freestyle for 10 and under boys for 18 years until it was recently broken.<ref>{{cite web|title=USA Swimming National Age Group Records|url=http://usaswimming.org/_Rainbow/Documents/e8f10a43-499e-4c61-a6e3-3d6abe76f29d/USA%20SWIMMING%20NATIONAL%20A%20G%20%20RECORDS%20L%20C.pdf|work=USASwimming.org|accessdate=January 4, 2014}}</ref> At age 12 he gave up swimming to pursue a career in basketball.
Humphries attended [[Hopkins High School]], where he led the team to a 25–2 record in 2002 and its first Minnesota state championship in 49 years.<ref name=usa/> He was named a 2003 [[McDonald's All-American Team|McDonald's All-American]] and named Second Team All-USA by [[USA Today]].<ref name=bio>{{cite web|title=Kris Humphries Info Page – Bio|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/kris_humphries/bio/|work=NBA.com|accessdate=April 14, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306120916/http://www.nba.com/playerfile/kris_humphries/bio/|archivedate=March 6, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> He was also named to the Super 25 Basketball Team by USA Today, named [[Minnesota Mr. Basketball]], and state player of the year by the [[Minneapolis Star Tribune]] and College Basketball News.<ref name=bio/> He was one of 10 finalists for the 2003 Naismith Prep Player of the Year Award, averaging a [[Double-double|double double]] in his final three seasons, averaging 25.7 [[point (basketball)|points]], 11.4 [[rebound (basketball)|rebounds]] and 5.0 [[assist (basketball)|assists]] a game as a senior.<ref name=bio/>
Considered a five-star recruit by [[Rivals.com]], Humphries was listed as the No. 2 power forward and the No. 15 player in the nation in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kris Humphries Recruiting Profile|url=https://n.rivals.com/content/prospects/maple/4700|work=Rivals.com|accessdate=January 6, 2012}}</ref>
Humphries accepted a scholarship offer to [[Duke University]], but later reconsidered and chose the [[Minnesota Golden Gophers|University of Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Duke releases McDonald's recruit Kris Humphries|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/college/mensbasketball/acc/2003-05-19-duke-humphries_x.htm|work=USAToday.com|date=May 19, 2003|accessdate=January 6, 2012}}</ref>
==College career== At Minnesota, Humphries was named 2004 [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] Freshman of the Year and named to the All-Big Ten First Team by the media and coaches. He was named Honorable Mention All-America by the [[Associated Press]] and by Rivals.com. He was the first freshman to lead the Big Ten in scoring and rebounding in the same season. He scored in double figures in all 29 games, with 16 point/rebound double-doubles on the season for Minnesota. He averaged 21.7 points and 10.1 rebounds (both tops in the Big Ten), while shooting .444 [[field goal percentage|percent from the field]] and .742 [[free throw|from the line]]. On February 18, 2004 he set a school record with 36 points in a game against [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana]]. He also set a school record for most points by a freshman for a season with 629 and was the first Big Ten freshman to be named conference Player of the Week in two of the first three weeks of the season. Humphries only played one season for Minnesota before declaring for the NBA Draft.
Although Humphries was personally successful at Minnesota, the team struggled. The Gophers finished 12–18, with a 3–13 record in the Big Ten during Humphries' lone season, tying Penn State for the worst record in the conference.<ref>{{cite web|title=NCAA Division I Basketball Standings - 2003-04|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/standings/_/year/2004|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=January 6, 2012}}</ref> Critics accused Humphries of playing selfishly, preferring to inflate his statistics and NBA draft stock rather than help the team win games.<ref>{{cite web|first=Michael |last=Rand |title=Top recruits have had problems at U |url=http://www.startribune.com/sports/gophers/83305812.html?page=2&c=y |work=StarTribune.com |date=February 10, 2010 |accessdate=February 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210225938/http://www.startribune.com/sports/gophers/83305812.html?page=2&c=y |archivedate=February 10, 2010 }}</ref> The team had a .500 record before his arrival and finished with a 10–6 conference record in the season after he left.
==Professional career==
===Utah Jazz (2004–2006)=== Humphries was [[NBA draft|drafted]] by the [[Utah Jazz]] with the 14th overall selection in the [[2004 NBA draft]].<ref>{{cite web|title=HUMPHRIES TAKEN BY UTAH WITH 14TH PICK OF NBA DRAFT|url=http://www.gophersports.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/062504aaa.html|work=GopherSports.com|date=June 25, 2004|accessdate=March 5, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kris Humphries Statistics|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/h/humphkr01.html|work=Basketball-Reference.com|accessdate=April 29, 2007}}</ref> He spent two seasons with the Jazz, averaging 3.6 ppg and 2.7 rpg in 11.6 minutes per game.<ref name=stats>{{cite web|title=Kris Humphries Info Page – Career Stats and Totals|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/kris_humphries/|work=NBA.com|accessdate=April 29, 2007}}</ref>
===Toronto Raptors (2006–2009)=== On June 8, 2006, Humphries was traded along with [[Robert Whaley]] to the [[Toronto Raptors]] in exchange for [[Rafael Paulo de Lara Araújo|Rafael Araújo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Raptors Acquire Kris Humphries & Robert Whaley for Araujo|url=http://www.nba.com/raptors/news/pressrelease_trade_060806.html|work=NBA.com|date=June 8, 2006|accessdate=April 29, 2007}}</ref> In the [[2006–07 NBA Season|2006–07 season]], after a slow start in which he did not receive many minutes from Raptors coach [[Sam Mitchell (basketball)|Sam Mitchell]], Humphries proved to be a valuable rebounder and energy player and contributed to the Raptors capturing their first ever [[Atlantic Division (NBA)|division]] title.<ref>{{cite web|first=Morgan|last=Campbell|title=Humphries, Jackson bring energy off Raptors' bench|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/2007/04/15/humphries_jackson_bring_energy_off_raptors_bench.html|work=TheStar.com|date=April 15, 2007|accessdate=April 15, 2007}}</ref> On March 28, 2007, he grabbed seven offensive rebounds in 27 minutes against the [[Miami Heat]], both a game-high<ref>{{cite web|title=Raptors Burn Heat, Grab Control of Third Place in East|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20070328/MIATOR/recap.html|work=NBA.com|date=March 28, 2007|accessdate=April 14, 2007}}</ref> and a career-high.<ref>{{cite web|first=Bruce |last=Arthur |title=Small Raptors come up big against Heat |url=http://www2.canada.com/topics/sports/basketball/raptorsstory.html?id=c0bca271-f678-41a2-9412-7a894ad63bbc&k=54662 |publisher=Canada.com |date=March 29, 2007 |accessdate=April 29, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140716175908/http://www2.canada.com/topics/sports/basketball/raptorsstory.html?id=c0bca271-f678-41a2-9412-7a894ad63bbc&k=54662 |archivedate=July 16, 2014 }}</ref> He followed up this performance with nine offensive and 18 total rebounds in a win against the [[Detroit Pistons]] on April 13, 2007, again both game and career-highs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Parker, Raptors Rally Past Pistons|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20070413/DETTOR/recap.html|work=NBA.com|date=April 13, 2007|accessdate=April 14, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Raptors Post Up |url=http://www.nba.com/raptors/news/postup_041307.html |work=NBA.com |date=April 13, 2007 |accessdate=April 13, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618183728/http://www.nba.com/raptors/news/postup_041307.html |archivedate=June 18, 2007 }}</ref> Humphries concluded his inaugural season with the Raptors with a career-high 3.1 rpg and .470 [[field goal percentage]], as well as 3.8 ppg.<ref name=stats/>
===Dallas Mavericks (2009–2010)=== [[File:Kris Humphries.jpg|thumb|right|130px|Humphries played with the [[Dallas Mavericks]] during the {{nbay|2009}} season.]] On July 9, 2009, Humphries, [[Shawn Marion]] and [[Nathan Jawai]] were traded to the [[Dallas Mavericks]] as a part of the four-team deal among Raptors, Mavericks, [[Orlando Magic]] and [[Memphis Grizzlies]].<ref>{{cite web|title=MAVERICKS ACQUIRE FOUR-TIME ALL-STAR SHAWN MARION |url=http://www.nba.com/mavericks/roster/shawnmarion.html |work=NBA.com |date=July 9, 2009 |accessdate=July 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130814132558/http://www.nba.com/mavericks/roster/shawnmarion.html |archivedate=August 14, 2013 }}</ref>
===New Jersey/Brooklyn Nets (2010–2013)=== On January 11, 2010 the Mavericks traded Humphries along with G/F [[Shawne Williams]] to the [[New Jersey Nets]] in order to re-acquire [[Eduardo Nájera]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Nets Acquire Kris Humphries and Shawne Williams from Dallas|url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Najera_Humphries_Trade_Release_100111.html|work=NBA.com|date=January 11, 2010|accessdate =January 12, 2010}}</ref> On January 27, 2010, Humphries scored a career-high 25 points against the Los Angeles Clippers. He previously recorded career highs of 15 and 21 points respectively as a New Jersey Net.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} The 2011 season was a breakout season for Humphries as he averaged a double-double in points and rebounds. On December 21, 2011, Humphries signed a one-year, $8 million contract with the [[New Jersey Nets]].<ref>{{cite web|title=NETS Re-Sign Kris Humphries|url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Humphries_Resigns_Release_111221.html|work=NBA.com|date=December 21, 2011|accessdate=December 21, 2011}}</ref>
On July 17, 2012, Humphries signed a two-year, $24 million contract with the Nets, who by that point had moved to [[Brooklyn]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Brooklyn Nets Agree to Re-Sign Kris Humphries|url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Humphries_Signing_Release_120717.html|work=NBA.com|date=July 17, 2012|accessdate=July 17, 2012}}</ref>
===Boston Celtics (2013–2014)=== On June 27, 2013, [[ESPN.com]] reported that the Nets and [[Boston Celtics]] had worked out a trade that would send Humphries and four other players ([[Keith Bogans]], [[MarShon Brooks]], [[Kris Joseph]] and [[Gerald Wallace]]) as well as three future first-round [[National Basketball Association Draft|draft]] picks to Boston in exchange for [[Kevin Garnett]], [[Paul Pierce]], and [[Jason Terry]] as well as [[D. J. White]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Nets, Celtics work out blockbuster|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/9429958/sources-boston-celtics-brooklyn-nets-agree-kevin-garnett-paul-pierce-deal|work=ESPN.com|date=June 27, 2013|accessdate=June 28, 2013}}</ref> The deal was finally completed on July 12, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/nets-acquire-nba-champions-kevin-garnett-paul-pierce-and-jason-terry|title=Nets Acquire NBA Champions Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce and Jason Terry|work=NBA.com|date=July 12, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2013}}</ref>
===Washington Wizards (2014–2016)=== [[File:Kris Humphries (15698676076).jpg|thumbnail|Humphries warming-up with Wizards in November 2014.]] On July 19, 2014, Humphries was acquired by the [[Washington Wizards]] in a sign-and-trade deal that sent a protected 2015 second round pick and a trade exception to the Boston Celtics.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/celtics/news/pressrelease/celtics-complete-trade-wizards|title=Celtics Complete Trade with Wizards|work=NBA.com|date=July 19, 2014|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> On October 9, 2014, he underwent successful surgery to repair nerve damage in his right small finger, and was subsequently sidelined for three to four weeks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wizardsmysticstoday.monumentalnetwork.com/2014/10/10/wizards-injury-update|title=WIZARDS INJURY UPDATE|work=WizardsMysticsToday.MonumentalNetwork.com|date=October 10, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref>
On November 14, 2015, Humphries made 5-of-8 three-pointers on his way to a game-high 23 points, helping the Wizards defeat the Orlando Magic 108–99. Prior to the 2015–16 season, Humphries had gone more than a decade since making a three-pointer. He hit two in his 2004–05 rookie season, and none after that, until this game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20151114/ORLWAS/gameinfo.html|title=Wizards beat Magic 108-99 to end 3-game skid|work=NBA.com|date=November 14, 2015|accessdate=November 14, 2015}}</ref>
===Phoenix Suns (2016)=== On February 18, 2016, Humphries was traded, along with [[DeJuan Blair]] and a 2016 protected first round draft pick, to the [[Phoenix Suns]] in exchange for [[Markieff Morris]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/suns/suns-trade-morris-first-round-pick|title=Suns Acquire First-Round Pick, Blair, Humphries from Washington for Morris|work=NBA.com|date=February 18, 2016|accessdate=February 18, 2016}}</ref> He made his debut for the Suns the following day in a 116–100 loss to the [[Houston Rockets]], recording 18 points and 12 rebounds in 27 minutes off the bench, becoming the 13th Suns player to have a double-double in his debut.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160219/HOUPHX/gameinfo.html|title=James Harden leads Rockets past free-falling Suns, 116-100|work=NBA.com|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc.|date=February 19, 2016|accessdate=February 20, 2016}}</ref> On February 28, after three starts in four games, he was waived by the Suns in a buyout agreement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/suns/suns-waive-humphries|title=Suns Waive Humphries|work=NBA.com|date=February 28, 2016|accessdate=February 28, 2016}}</ref>
===Atlanta Hawks (2016–2017)=== On March 1, 2016, Humphries signed with the [[Atlanta Hawks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/hawks/news/hawks-sign-kris-humphries|title=Hawks Sign Kris Humphries|work=NBA.com|date=March 1, 2016|accessdate=March 1, 2016}}</ref> Three days later, he made his debut for the Hawks in a 106–77 win over the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], recording 14 points, eight rebounds, one steal and one block in 22 minutes off the bench.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/games/20160304/ATLLAL/gameinfo.html|title=Hawks get balanced scoring in trampling Lakers 106-77|work=NBA.com|date=March 5, 2016|accessdate=March 5, 2016}}</ref>
On July 15, 2016, Humphries re-signed with the Hawks.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nba.com/hawks/features/hawks-re-sign-humphries-add-jack-delaney|title=Hawks Re-Sign Humphries, Add Jack & Delaney|work=NBA.com|date=July 15, 2016|accessdate=July 15, 2016}}</ref>
===2017–18 season=== On September 25, 2017, Humphries signed with the [[Philadelphia 76ers]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Sixers Sign Humphries, Okafor; Set Training Camp Roster|url=http://www.nba.com/sixers/news/sixers-sign-humphries-okafor-set-training-camp-roster|website=NBA.com|accessdate=September 25, 2017|date=September 25, 2017}}</ref> but was waived on October 14, 2017, as one of the final roster cuts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sixers Waive Three Players|url=http://www.nba.com/sixers/news/sixers-waive-three-players|website=NBA.com|accessdate=October 14, 2017|date=October 14, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Humphries began dating reality TV personality [[Kim Kardashian]] in October 2010. They became engaged in May 2011,<ref>{{cite news|first=Jocelyn|last=Vena|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1673479/kim-kardashian-kris-humphries-timeline.jhtml|title=Kim Kardashian And Kris Humphries: A Timeline|work=MTV.com|date=October 31, 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> and married on August 20, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://khitschicago.radio.com/2011/05/25/kardashian-engaged/|title=Kim Kardashian Is Engaged|date=May 25, 2011|work=KHitsChicago.Radio.com|accessdate=May 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110529130137/http://khitschicago.radio.com/2011/05/25/kardashian-engaged/|archivedate=May 29, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> A two-part TV special showing the preparations and the wedding itself aired on [[E!]] in early October 2011, amidst what ''[[The Washington Post]]'' called a "media blitz" related to the wedding.<ref>{{cite news|first=Sarah Anne|last=Hughes|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/celebritology/post/kim-kardashian-wedding-special-to-air-this-sunday-will-you-watch-video/2011/10/07/gIQATLFQTL_blog.html|title=Kim Kardashian wedding special to air this Sunday: Will you watch?|date=October 7, 2011|accessdate=December 2, 2011|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> On October 31, 2011, it was announced that Kardashian had filed for divorce from Humphries after 72 days of marriage.<ref>{{cite web|first=Justin|last=Harp|title=Updated: Kim Kardashian files for divorce from Kris Humphries|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/celebrity/news/a348420/kim-kardashian-filing-for-divorce-from-kris-humphries-today.html|work=DigitalSpy.com|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|date=October 31, 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Kim Kardashian And Kris Humphries Marriage Is Over!|url=http://us99country.radio.com/2011/10/31/apparently-the-kim-kardashian-and-kris-humphries-marriage-is-over/|work=WUSN-FM/US99.5|date=October 31, 2011|accessdate=October 31, 2011}}</ref> On December 1, 2011, Humphries filed his response to Kardashian's petition, requesting an annulment on the grounds of fraud or a decree of legal separation rather than Kardashian requested divorce.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kris Humphries' Annulment Filing: Read It Here Now!|url=http://www.eonline.com/ca/news/277969/kris-humphries-annulment-filing-read-it-here-now|publisher=EOnline.com|date=December 1, 2011|accessdate=December 2, 2011}}</ref> Several news outlets have surmised that Kardashian's marriage to Humphries was merely a publicity stunt for financial gain orchestrated by E! Entertainment, Kris and Kim Kardashian to promote the Kardashian family's brand and their subsequent television ventures.<ref>{{cite news|title=Was Kardashian marriage a sham? |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/video/breaking/chi-video-was-kim-kardashian-marriage-divorce-a-sham-20111101,0,7143953.htmlstory |work=Chicago Tribune |date=November 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102141236/http://www.chicagotribune.com/video/breaking/chi-video-was-kim-kardashian-marriage-divorce-a-sham-20111101%2C0%2C7143953.htmlstory |archivedate=November 2, 2011 |df= }}</ref> In April 2013, after a lengthy legal battle, Humphries and Kardashian reached a divorce settlement.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kris Humphries divorce agreed on|url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/nba/story/_/id/9189962/kim-kardashian-kris-humphries-agree-divorce-terms|publisher=ESPN.com|date=April 19, 2013|accessdate=April 19, 2013}}</ref> Their divorce was finalized on June 3, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries finalize divorce|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/kim-kardashian-and-kris-humphries-finalize-divorce/|publisher=CBSNews.com|date=June 4, 2013|accessdate=June 4, 2013}}</ref>

==International career== Humphries was on the 2002 U.S. Junior World Championship Qualifying Tournament Team, alongside future Raptors' teammate [[Chris Bosh]].<ref name=bio/> The team finished with a 4–1 record and the bronze medal and qualified for a berth in the 2003 [[FIBA]] Junior World Championship.<ref name=usa/> Humphries averaged 9.0 ppg and 5.0 rpg in five games.<ref name=usa/>
